HEADLINE: A China Odyssey Sheds Light on a Murky Past, and Hints at the Future 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN

DATELINE: CHEN DONG VILLAGE, China 

 BODY:
The Chens of Yongding County, all 20 generations of them, in an arc that continues after half a millennium, are chronicled in a local genealogy, a book of more than a thousand pages.
 Their fortunes have naturally risen and fallen with China's turbulent history, from poverty and plague to well-being, from peace to the Cultural Revolution. 
 That dynamic goes on to this day, when some members of the youngest generation scratch by in a crumbling three-story homestead, without heat or plumbing, while others have moved to thriving cities nearby, to make their mark in China's buoyant economy.
Page 1,057 of this chronicle speaks of a particular favorite son, Chen Nanqing, who left the village in the 1930's, eventually went to Taiwan and then made his way to New Jersey, where he became a professor.
He was my father. 
Genealogy may be an alluring pastime for many Americans, and sometimes a frustrating one as it reaches back to the country and language of emigration. But it can also provide bracing revelations about one's family. For me, a reporter on assignment in China, not only did a recent visit to this ancestral village bring to life a family heritage that was all but unknown, but it also unearthed a riddle about my father.
He left the village as a boy of 12, seldom to speak of it, never to return. Yet in his later years, he often sent large sums of money home, gave advice to relatives and wrote with pride of the accomplishments of his family in America. All this was news to me. 
"Your father always cared a lot about his hometown," said Lu Jisheng, a grandnephew of my grandmother, Lu Yajin, whose name was also unknown to me. "He's very famous. The most famous person in the village."

Poor but Ambitious
It was never easy to get in or out of Chen Dong, in the rugged and mountainous southwestern corner of Yongding County in Fujian Province, near the border with Guangdong Province. For most of the 20th century, there were no paved roads in the area, so walking to the nearest town could take days.
For generations, the Chens worked as farmers and lived in one of Yongding County's famous earthen buildings, called "tulou."
"It's like a hotel, because everyone lives in a room," said Chen Dawen, a cousin, who said that as many as 200 Chens once lived in our family's compound, called Dehuilou.
My father was born Chen Nanqing (a name I had never heard) in 1920, according to the local genealogy book, and not in 1925, as he later told everyone, even my mother.
His father, my grandfather, Chen Tieqin, was evidently an outstanding student; he went to school in Xiamen, about 140 miles away. His father, my great-grandfather, whose pen name was Chen Yintang, was a teacher and poet of some renown. 
Grandfather died of the plague in 1923, at 22. Grandmother was bedridden with illness, her mouth drooling, before dying in 1929, at about 26.
Other relatives raised my father, an only child. When he was about 12, my great-grandfather sent him to a school in Dabu, about 25 miles away in Guangdong Province, said Su Huadi, my grandmother's sister-in-law, who is 93 and my oldest relative in the village.
He never went home.
The next stage of his life is murkier. Relatives say he joined an elite unit of the Nationalist army to fight the Japanese, before enrolling at National Chengchi University. At some point, he changed his Chinese name to Chen Qing, adopted a new English one, King Chen, and left for Taiwan.
Eventually, he went to America, became a professor of political science and settled in Livingston, N.J. He married and had two sons.
As he progressed in the world, the family in Chen Dong struggled. During the 1930's, Dehuilou was burned down, perhaps by Communists who had heard that the Chens, like many members of the nomadic Hakka clan, were sympathetic to the Nationalists. (It was later rebuilt.)
During the Cultural Revolution of the 1960's and 1970's, local officials affixed white banners to Chen homes, branding their residents "counterrevolutionaries" because of their blood ties with those who had gone overseas. No one could go to school for years. Sometimes, they ate only tree leaves. At least one relative was jailed. He died shortly after being released.
"We all suffered," said Chen Dahua, who at 57 is the oldest male of my generation. "Two generations were lost."
All that while my father seemed to seldom think twice about his roots. "He never talked about these things, and I never asked," said my mother. "But I also think he liked being abroad, far from home."
That evidently began to change after China began to open to the West, when he reconnected with Chen Dong through an act of filial devotion. In 1978, when he heard about the government's plan to reclaim my grandparents' burial ground to build a public bathroom, he sent several hundred dollars to help.
This was a turning point. Every year, during the holidays, he sent money. Once, he sent $60 to one cousin as a wedding gift. Another time, he sent $380 to be divided among five families.
My relatives still have his letters. In one from the late-1980's, he wrote with pride that my younger brother, Don, and I were studying at Yale, but that he had to borrow a lot of money to pay for our educations. In another, he encouraged his relatives to leave the countryside for cities like Zhangzhou or Xiamen.
"He said that there were better opportunities in the cities to develop, and to have better lives," said Chen Dahua. "He said that while we would never starve as farmers, we would never be full, either."
In his last letter home, written just before he died in June 1993, he sent $100 to a cousin to help with the care of his ailing wife. For the first time, he also signed the letter with his original name; before, he had always used my name, for reasons that remain unclear.

A Hometown Changed
Chen Dong first got electricity in the late 1970's. Five years ago, there were no phones. Now, many people have both regular phone service and cellphones.
About 10 years ago, the government paved the dirt path that connected the village, which has no more than 2,000 residents, to bigger towns such as Longyan and Dabu. About three years ago, a new train station opened nearby, making it possible to go to Guangzhou, which used to take days to reach, in nine hours.
The paved road is already deteriorating from overuse, particularly from trucks carting coal and cement, making some spots nearly impassable.
The trip is starkly beautiful and sometimes incongruous, grinding up the mountains in second gear and slaloming down past the endless convoys of blue construction trucks. Past lush banana fields. Past the occasional tour bus. Past cement factory after cement factory -- 30 in all, by Chen Dahua's count -- most of them built within the last 10 years.
Sometimes, it is hard to tell where the plumes of smoke end and the clouds begin.
But no one in our family, Chen Dahua said, works at these factories. Instead, more Chens, particularly the younger ones, are heading to Xiamen and Guangzhou. So the family's farms and small roadside stores are minded by the older generation, who spend most of their days watching television, doing chores and inviting people over for tea.
One cousin, Chen Dawen, worked as a farmer before landing a job two years ago at a Guangdong electronics factory run by a relative from Taiwan. He is 42, and makes more money there (roughly $580 a year) than the average farmer in Fujian (about $430), though his income is still below the average urban resident's (about $1,020). But his family still lives here, and he can afford to return home only twice a year.
Now, he views the world through the lens of the middle class.
"Everybody should make more money, but there should be poor people too," he said. "Who's going to sweep the streets?"
My generation shares the middle name of "da," or "big." My brother -- Chen Datong in Chinese -- and I -- Chen Dawei -- are the youngest, because my father did not have children until he was 46.
No one in the "da" generation in China had more than a junior high or high school education. But that is not true for the next generation -- "sheng," or "birth" for the boys, and "mei," or "beautiful," for the girls.
Chen Dahua's son, Yunsheng, a 23-year-old computer whiz, attends college in Guangzhou and watches "Forrest Gump" on his computer. Two female relatives, Meixiang and Meizhao, both 25, are studying for master's degrees at Fujian Teacher's University in Fuzhou. Another relative, Chen Taisheng, is a Xiamen government official who is an expert on international trade issues.
A few years ago, Chen Dahua's father, who lives in Taiwan, helped the family open a store in the ever-expanding city of Zhangzhou. Another of Chen Dahua's sons, together with his daughter, run the store now, which sells souvenirs, toys and art.
"This generation is better off than our generation," said Chen Dahua. "They have more freedom. More opportunities."

A Warm Family Welcome
When I arrive in Chen Dong Village, the family sets off a round of celebratory firecrackers. Family members ask in heavily accented Mandarin if I can speak Hakka, as my father presumably did. I say no -- I did not even know we were Hakka.
Then we try to sort out the usual confusion over ages (they still follow the lunar calendar, which adds a year) and names (Chen Dahua's grandchildren call me "gong gong," or grandpa, though I am only 36.)
No one resembles my father, and no one sees my father in me, based on their fading memories or the blurry photos he sent. But everyone knows about me.
Chen Dawen says that whenever a China Airlines plane crashes, or a big news event occurs, he wonders whether I am safe, or whether I am covering it as a journalist.
"I kept on looking for your name after Sept. 11, hoping I wouldn't see it," he says. "Same thing for Iraq."
Shortly after my arrival, we hike up a slippery mountain path and pay our respects to my grandparents, and my great-grandfather, who are buried in a serene spot overlooking a valley of rice paddies. Later, we visit the earthen buildings where my grandmother lived, and where my father grew up, which are about a 15-minute walk apart. One cousin, Chen Danian, explains that the family has even been preserving my legal rights to the rooms in Dehuilou where my father grew up, and where 60 Chens still live. 
"This is yours," he says, pointing to a small room now used for storage. He points to two other rooms, which are locked. "These two are yours, too. They're a little messy. But we can clean it up for you." At Chen Dahua's house, the family pulls out the genealogy book, published in 1998. I scrutinize page 1,059, where the family tree lists my name, and page 1,057, where my father is listed, and page 1,055, my grandfather's page, and so on.
I notice an error: the book says that my brother and I have Ph.D.'s. Perhaps this is what my father told his relatives many years ago, if only because he expected as much.
I wait for questions about what life is like in America, how much money people make, whether we feel free -- questions that ordinary Chinese often ask. But they do not ask. Instead, they are sweet and generous, without making judgments.
Everybody asks about my wife and our daughters, whose pictures are contained on my computer. Naturally, they assume that we will have a boy next time. I smile and mutter something vague. 
At dinner, the relatives insist that I sit with all the "da brothers." The Chen men exchange toasts of the local brew, Gold Rider beer, and tell stories into the late hours of the inky, rural night.
"Before, we were just a rumor, or some stories, right?" says Chen Dawen. "Now, we're reality. You should visit more often. Bring your brother next time."

HEADLINE: As North Korean Men Turn to Business, Women Join the Army 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea 

 BODY:
While inspecting an army unit recently, North Korea's leader admired how the soldiers had "spruced up" their post, showing the revolutionary ardor "required by the party's slogan: Let us train, study and live like the anti-Japanese guerrillas."
 Then, according to the state news agency, Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader, "underscored the need to pay great attention to the service and living of the servicewomen." 
 Increasingly, women fill the baggy brown uniforms of the vaunted "1.1 million-man" Korean People's Army. 
"Feminization" of the North Korean military is a hot new topic for American military analysts trying to size up North Korea, one of the most militarized societies on earth, Dr. Alexandre Y. Mansourov, a former Russian diplomat who is now an American citizen and an analyst specializing in Korea, said from Hawaii, where he teaches at the Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies, a government-financed center.
Running short of men, North Korea earlier this year lowered the draft age for men to 16, lowered minimum height requirements to 4 feet 9 inches and started drafting women for all-women units.
Where have all the men gone?
"A lot of the males have fled," said Dr. Mansourov. He estimated that about 2 percent of North Korea's population had fled to China in recent years. Another 5 percent probably died in the famine of the mid-1990's.
But a lot of young men are ducking the draft -- and the seven-year hitch it entails -- in order to make money in small businesses.
Last year, North Korea removed price controls on most goods, admitting that the state could no longer dole out food, clothing and housing. With cash being king in the new economy, many young men may realize that their family's survival now depends on earning money, often on the semilegal market fringe.
"A lot of men are beginning to think about the importance of money," said Song Young Sun, director of security policy at the Korea Institute for Defense Analyses, a government agency. "In the past, if you stayed in the military, you were guaranteed food, clothing and social success."
Indeed, under North Korea's longstanding "military first" policy, army service was seen to be so advantageous that until last year there was not even a draft.
Military service "no longer brings the perks and benefits that entrepreneurship does," said Dr. Mansourov, who lived in North Korea as a Soviet diplomat in the late 1980's. "They switched to a conscription base because males refused to serve. People of draftable age prefer to go into small business."
Asked what portion of North Korea's military is made up of women, he declined to give an estimate, saying, "That is classified." 
He added, however, that one could "just follow Kim Jong Il's on-site inspections," of the military. "If he visited 36 units last year, as was reported, at least one-third of them were female units."
A recent official photograph from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, showed a sea of brown-uniformed army officers arrayed for a rally marking the 50th anniversary of the armistice that ended the Korean War. Ten of the 40 officers in the front four rows were women.
In South Korea, where the 26-month, mandatory military service for men is increasingly unpopular, the first women are graduating from the South Korean service academies.
Over all, however, only 3,000 women are in South Korea's military, less than half of 1 percent of the total.

HEADLINE: FOLLOWING UP 

BYLINE:  By Joseph P. Fried

 BODY:
Using One Blackout To Illuminate Another
 When the blackout hit on Thursday, Richard L. Dunham of rural Malden Bridge in upstate New York lost power at his home for only a bit more than an hour. 
 In fact, he said, because it was daylight and he did not have his lights or television on, he did not even know that his home, southeast of Albany, had been blacked out until relatives who had seen the news called from Florida and Seattle. And by then, his power had been restored. 
Mr. Dunham's most minor involvement with the blackout was in distinct contrast with his spotlighted involvement with the giant power failure that embraced New York City and its suburbs in 1977.
Back then, he was chairman of the Federal Power Commission, and he oversaw the investigation that found that failure to have stemmed from inadequate equipment and flawed emergency procedures on the part of Consolidated Edison.
Con Ed had called the 1977 blackout "an act of God," noting that it had been touched off by lightning strikes on power lines. Mr. Dunham called the blackout "clearly insupportable" and "intolerable."
Mr. Dunham, a Ford administration holdover during Jimmy Carter's presidency and a former New York State budget director, left government service for the private sector shortly after his front-page exchange with Con Ed.
On Friday, the retired Mr. Dunham, 73, recalled having spoken with Abraham D. Beame, New York's mayor in 1977, after the blackout began on the night of July 13. "He was in a panic," Mr. Dunham said.
Looting and arson erupted in the city's poorer neighborhoods that night. The lights stayed out for 25 hours in some areas.
As for last week's episode, "what puzzles me," Mr. Dunham said, is that "after our report in 1977, a lot more safeguards were put in so that if something happened in a particular area, that area would be isolated and would be the only area blacked out and it would be kept from spreading."
But he said it was too early to assess those safeguards "until we find out what actually happened" last week.
After leaving the government, Mr. Dunham was president of the Zinder Companies, an economic and regulatory consulting group. Now, he has some free advice for those investigating last week's failure: Don't whitewash the findings. "It's too important an issue," he said.
Also, he said: "I'm anxious to find out what happened. It's fascinating."

A Clamor Against Bias Gets a Little Louder
In May 2001, 11 blacks and Hispanics, current and former employees of the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, accused the agency in a lawsuit of discrimination in hiring and promotions. Parks officials called the accusations unfounded.
Recently, a court ruling greatly enlarged the plaintiff group. It designated the suit as a class action on behalf of all current and former black and Hispanic workers employed full time at the agency since May 1998.
The suit now covers about 2,000 people, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, Lewis M. Steel, above, said last week.
Mr. Steel called the ruling, by Judge Denny Chin of Federal District Court in Manhattan, a "major development." He added that if the accusations were upheld in a trial, the outcome was now more likely to be an order that the department revamp its overall hiring and promotion policies, rather than simply remedy the complaints of 11 employees.
Though the city had fought the plaintiffs' request for class-action status, Barbara Butler, a senior counsel with the city's Law Department, said last week that the granting of it was "standard procedure."

HEADLINE: Professor Teaches Change in His Indian Village 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN

DATELINE: MIRDHA, India 

 BODY:
Along fields so green they seemed to vibrate with color, Jagadish Shukla walked toward his childhood home.
 There, a room specially built for his visits waited, as did a generator rented so fans could cool him in the Indian heat -- his family's modest effort to provide the comforts of his Bethesda, Md., home in this rural village. 
 Professor Shukla, 59, has lived for 32 years in the United States and is now its citizen. He is a professor at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., and a climatologist who directs the Center for Ocean-Land-Atmosphere Studies in Calverton, Md.
But he has never relinquished his past or forgotten his home. Every year since leaving India, he has returned to this village of 1,500 people, where he grew up and where his family still lives. 
Like many "nonresident Indians," or "N.R.I.'s," he has used his relative wealth earned in America to pay for the education of his siblings' children here, their marriages, their home improvements, their mother's funeral and, in lean times, their food -- "95 percent" of the family's needs, said his older brother, Mahendra Pratap Shukla.
But in recent years he has taken his commitment a step further, setting aside 10 percent of his income for more ambitious projects that are testing the limits of change in a place where the clock is still set by the sun and cows wander down muddy lanes past men in the long loincloths known as lungi. 
Bill Clinton once suggested that if every nonresident Indian adopted an Indian village, it could transform the country. Professor Shukla's own experience shows the truth and fallacy of that statement.
His efforts have bettered the lives of individuals here. Yet he still seeks an answer to the question, long pondered by Indians at home and abroad, of how to bring the country's hundreds of thousands of villages, even his own, into the 21st century. 
"That's the real challenge," Professor Shukla said during a two-day visit home. "What will it take to transform the other India?"
Mirdha is set in the eastern reaches of India's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, a region with a reputation for poverty and backwardness. 
With power for at most eight hours a day, the village plunges into blackness at night. Water comes only through inconstant hand pumps. Most residents still make their living farming, but as generations divide the land into smaller pieces, the livings are ever more meager. 
Most residents relieve themselves in open fields, the women only after dark. The primary school is a decrepit two-room structure with no desks or chairs, and 70 percent of the children drop out before junior high, said the village leader.
With $50,000 of his own money and $50,000 given by others, Professor Shukla has built a community college, rare in any Indian village. He has also started an after-hours program for children not enrolled in primary school and opened a small medical dispensary. His younger brother, Shri Ram Shukla, oversees the projects.
But while Professor Shukla fantasizes about a giant network of N.R.I.'s like him replicating tested ideas in a constellation of villages, he concedes that, ultimately, they cannot substitute for government. 
After only six months, for example, the medical dispensary has been overrun and is dispensing double the amount of free medicine budgeted. Professor Shukla frets that it will soon be unsustainable.
"Everything is beginning," he said. "In some ways we are groping." 
Professor Shukla has also encountered an entrenched village culture. While villagers speak positively, and sometimes glowingly, of his investment, no one wants to part with the land needed for one of his pet projects -- laying paths in place of muddy patches caused by poor drainage. 
His new drive for 100 percent literacy has raised questions, half-joking but half-serious, about who will labor in the homes and fields.
Nor is everyone convinced he can really bring change. "Everyone said, 'O.K., O.K., O.K.,' but I can tell you it's simply not possible in the village," Vishva Nath Shukla, 70, said one evening of Professor Shukla's plans.
One retired teacher, Baban Singh, 70, said nothing ever changed in the village because no one would cooperate. If someone takes initiative, he said, "Everyone thinks: 'What is his agenda? How is he trying to make money?' "
Even Professor Shukla provokes such suspicions, said Mr. Singh: "People do talk -- Why is he spending the money? Where is he getting it? What are his interests?"
In part what Professor Shukla wants to do -- through the committees he has formed, the meetings he has held and especially the college he has already built -- is change the notion that change is not possible.
Because he is now as much outsider as insider, the danger is that even his help affirms that change cannot come from within. "He's very well-respected, people listen to him," said Arjun Sharma, a laborer. "With him it might be possible. Without him, it's not."
Wary of cultivating overdependence even within his own family, Professor Shukla has never financed luxury living, although he does dole out cash gifts when he leaves. The house got an indoor toilet only recently and still has no sink or shower.
To encourage villagers' self-sufficiency, he gave them a sermon on the "tipping point," trying to explain that maintaining a certain standard of cleanliness would encourage people to keep an area clean.
Like one-fourth of the villagers, Professor Shukla is a Brahmin, and his notions of uplift are characteristic of the caste of the elite. His father, a teacher who was then the only educated man in the village, started its primary school.
As a result, Mr. Singh, the retired teacher, reminded Professor Shukla that the village had already made some progress.
"There was a time when anyone who received a letter would go to your house and ask your father to read the letter," Mr. Singh said. "Now there are plenty of people who can read and write."
Professor Shukla, who with his silver hair and pressed shirts looks as much Boston Brahmin as Indian one, is particularly proud of the high standards of the school he has opened himself, Gandhi Degree College, where admissions are by merit.
Professor Shukla's subversive goal is to teach Gandhian principles -- honesty, perseverance, selflessness -- in a country where they are increasingly unfashionable. He insisted on a no-cheating policy, although cheating is rampant in many area colleges. At first the policy deterred some students, but now it draws them. The college is at capacity with 500 students, 70 percent of them women. 
Professor Shukla holds two doctorates, including one from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and has broken scientific ground by demonstrating that predictability exists within chaos in climate.
But in the village, he said, a scientific mind is "not a help." His brothers often remind him of the chaos of life -- emotion, culture and other unscientific variables.
His reflexive description is that nothing has changed in the village, but a morning walk during this visit made him rethink that.
He saw new businesses attaching like barnacles along an expanding road system. He saw new homes, often built with the earnings of relatives who, like him, had migrated, if only to other states.
He learned that village Dalits, or untouchables as they were once known, no longer bother with making leather from dead cows, an occupation to which caste once consigned them, because there were now more profitable ways to make a living.
The need to know how things really work so he can better invest his money has convinced him that he should start spending 10 percent of his time in Mirdha each year. He concedes that it will be a challenge.
"After five days I'm looking for a comfortable hotel," he said of his limited tolerance for personal suffering. "What a man Gandhi was."

Of the college's 500 students, 70 percent are women.; Jagadish Shukla, left, stopped to talk to a villager during a walk through Mirdha, India, where he grew up and where his family lives. Professor Shukla resides in the United States but invests time and money in the village. (Photographs by Amy Waldman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS; 
Echo of Adirondacks At a Wisconsin Pond

BYLINE:  By John van Vliet

 BODY:
At Doc's Pond in northern Wisconsin the evening rise was on. Brook trout measured in pounds, not inches, rolled on the inky, bog-stained surface of the one-acre pond like solitary orcas. Around the shore, a fringe of close-mown grass -- wide enough to allow for a fly angler's backcast -- separated the dark water from the dense woods of white birch and maple and towering remnant old-growth white pine. My friend Cliff and I stood on the bank with our fly rods and watched the trout.
 Cliff has been fishing this manicured pond since he was old enough to keep both ends of a bamboo fly rod off the ground at the same time, as did his father, grandfather and great-grandfather before him. Like almost everything on the surrounding thousand acres, this pond has changed little since 1890, when it was first stocked with trout. On an old birch at the edge of the woods a simple blue-and-white enamel sign reminds any uninvited guests who make it past the caretaker's cabin that this is private property. 
 Through the trees to the west of Doc's Pond is a larger lake, nearly a mile long. Along the south shore are a handful of cabins that bear a striking resemblance to the great camps of the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York. One, a Swiss-style chalet, is reminiscent of North Point, Carnegie's great camp on Raquette Lake designed by the architect William Coulter. Others resemble designs by William West Durant or William Distin. And it's no accident: the men who purchased this low, rolling land from the railroad in the late 1880's were men of wealth and privilege, leaders of Chicago's industries, lumber barons and railroad builders. And like their East Coast counterparts, they wanted their wilderness carefully cultivated and their rustic retreat endowed with creature comforts. They looked to the camps and clubs of Maine and New York, Michigan and New Brunswick, as the standards for their new private sporting enclave in the Wisconsin woods.
Like many of the Midwestern clubs, this one was carefully situated near a handful of world-class trout rivers that drain the glacial uplands above Lake Michigan: the Peshtigo, the Menomonee, the Oconto, the Pine, and others. But Works Progress Administration dam projects, the Great Depression, a handful of wars, a changing economy and shifting tastes and fortunes have taken a toll on these clubs.
I asked Cliff how many private clubs like this still existed in the region and was surprised to hear him rattle off a half-dozen names. He told me that each club had adapted to a century of change in a different way. Some were bought out by a single member, some went public and abandoned exclusivity, others simply faded away. But Cliff's family was here at the start, and he is optimistic that the club can adapt to social and economic change. He was made a member -- succeeding his father, who still fishes here -- just last year.
The members of this club are understandably protective of their privacy. There is neither a club Web site nor published directions to the place. But they have always been gracious and candid and welcoming to me.
Though the club's roots are in the 19th century, its attitude is distinctly 21st. The focus of the club has shifted over the decades from hunting and fishing to family activities and golf.
I peppered Cliff with questions about the history of the club (Which cabin is oldest? Who were the first members? Who would be eligible for membership today?), but he deflected them as he made another cast. "You should really ask Tom," he told me.
Tom is by all accounts the unofficial club historian. He knows every member, the history of every cabin, and the location of every school of crappies and bass in the big lake. And he should know these things; he's the son of the former club manager. "My father was born in the cook's house," he said with a laugh as he pulled a crappie out from under a dock with his fly rod. "My grandfather was club manager, and his father, my great-grandfather, was the manager beginning in 1892."
Tom's father died when Tom was 20, and though the club invited his mother to stay on, she left a year later, leaving the house where Tom and his brother Peter grew up. It was a double loss to Tom, whose world to that point had been shaped by his father and their life within the fence that enclosed the club property. "I was 16 before I realized my father didn't own the place," he confessed. But the club members always made him feel welcome.
Tom, who is now in his 40's, went on to a successful career in the financial world of Chicago. And on the weekend I was there, he was elected the club's newest member. His new cabin (built in 1912) is within sight of the house where he spent his childhood. And just outside the club's gates, in a small rural cemetery, Tom's father is buried.
As the sun sank through the trees, Cliff and I sipped our before-dinner drinks and puffed on Dominican cigars. We cast black Woolly Buggers into Doc's Pond and stripped them in slowly. But the trout seemed as preoccupied as we were, and ignored our offerings. 
Cliff invites me to the club at least twice a year, and each morning of every visit he and I walk to a larger pond a half-mile from Doc's and launch the old rowboat before breakfast. Our luck is always better there. Most mornings produce at least one trout over three pounds, with six-pound trout not uncommon.
Before my stay was over, I caught and released two browns and a brook trout over two pounds and a three-and-a-half-pound rainbow from the larger pond, as well as seven large crappies, which I kept for a friend, from the big lake. All on an olive-and-peacock caddis emerger I had tied after dinner beside the fireplace in Cliff's cabin.
And at least one evening of each visit we fish this pond until it is time for dinner. If tradition is the hinge pin on which these old clubs turn, then standing there watching the trout rise on Doc's Pond is ours.

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: THE STATES; 
Governors See Obstacles To a Unified Energy Stand

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
As life in the Northeast slowly returned to normal after this week's widespread electrical blackout, the National Governors Association convened its four-day summer meeting here today with a full agenda of major issues to discuss. Electricity transmission was not among them.
 With most states scrambling to close budget deficits and Medicare costs eating away at revenues, the chairman of the association, Gov. Paul E. Patton of Kentucky, said problems that might have contributed to millions of people losing power were too complicated for the organization to speak as a unified voice. 
 "This is an area where different states have competing interests," Mr. Patton, a Democrat, said at the association's opening news conference. "The N.G.A. is not equipped to adopt a unified strategy. We are only effective dealing on a relatively nonpartisan basis when there is a relative unanimity of opinion."
The reluctance of the association to press for improvements in the nation's electricity grid, even in the aftermath of a malfunction that affected millions of people, reflects the complexity of problems that need to be fixed and the number of jurisdictions that are demanding a say in how. Because the movement of electricity is instantaneous andpower grids are connected, local, state and federal governments all have claims to oversight and responsibility.
In recent years, more acute problems facing the states, like rising unemployment and growing budget gaps, have pushed energy transmission issues down the governors' list of priorities. Two years ago, Mr. Patton was chairman of the association's Task Force on Electricity, which later produced a 30-page report that included nine recommendations to revitalize the nation's system for generating and moving electricity.
But its conclusions came with the notation that the recommendations "should not be considered N.G.A. policy," and, reflecting the enormous range of problems that require collaboration from all levels of government, the recommendations were offered as being voluntary.
Diane Shea, director of the association's Natural Resources Committee, said one of the report's foremost suggestions, that states form multistate entities to coordinate transmission planning and location, led to the creation of only one, the Midwestern Independent System Operator, uniting efforts in Ohio, Indiana, Illinois and several other states.
"States have always been very protective about land use," Ms. Shea said about why more such regional efforts have not formed and why federal policy is difficult to create. "When there are proposals to take away control, states are very reluctant to have their authority preempted by federal entities far removed from local concerns."
Fears of intrusion by the federal government have led to at least one instance in which the association has spoken with a single voice. Ms. Shea said that the governors opposed a provision of the energy bill passed by the House that would limit states to a period of 180 days to approve a company's bid to build new transmission lines, after which the company could appeal to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.
The latest energy bill passed by the Senate has no such provision.
John Thomasian, the association's director for best practices, said the governors would likely discuss the blackout in private sessions, which unlike many of their meetings are closed to reporters.
This week's energy problems in the Northeast notwithstanding, transmission-related issues might become more important to the governors. On Tuesday, when the meetings end, Mr. Patton's chairmanship passes to Gov. Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho, a Republican, who said today that he would make electrical transmission issues a higher priority for his fellow governors.
"The rest of the country just felt a phenomenon that many thought was specific to the West," Mr. Kempthorne said, comparing the latest outages to blackouts that California and other Western states have experienced in recent years. "It's very appropriate to take some of the lessons we learned into perspective and combine them with those from our colleagues in the East."
Mr. Kempthorne, a former chairman of the Western Governors Association, also suggested that the national group would take a more active role in influencing federal policy on energy. Despite Mr. Patton's contention that power-grid problems were too unwieldy for such a group, Mr. Kempthorne cited a recent bipartisan effort by Western governors that resulted in the federal government's providing $700 million to improve transmission facilities in the Pacific Northwest.

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: VISITORS; 
So, Fewer Sights to See? Tourists Take It in Stride

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES and DAISY HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
Shelley Jackson has her punch line ready.
 For months, Ms. Jackson had looked forward to making a trip to New York from her native England with her husband and three children. They arrived in town Thursday afternoon armed with a typical itinerary: Central Park, Empire State Building,Statue of Liberty. 
 But when she returns home to Farnborough Village, she already has an answer for anyone who asks what she saw in New York. "We couldn't see anything," said Ms. Jackson, 41, barely suppressing a chuckle, "because the lights were out!"
Ms. Jackson's response says much about how many tourists in New York City have reacted to the blackout of 2003. Despite the obvious inconveniences -- closed attractions, long lines at airports -- many visitors to the city reacted with much the same resilience, aplomb, and, yes, good humor of native New Yorkers.
If after terror attacks, the economic downturn and other calamities, perseverance has somehow become encoded into the DNA of residents of the five boroughs, then a bit of it may have rubbed off on those who have visited the city in recent days.
Just consider what Ms. Jackson -- who over the past several days has watched many of her fellow tourists sleep on sidewalks, miss Broadway shows and endure mammoth traffic jams -- said of the blackout: "You just have to go with it."
And go she did. Like many tourists, Ms. Jackson continued her New York trip as planned -- well, almost. Yesterday, Ms. Jackson; her husband, Mark; and their children, Ben, 11, Jos, 10, and Lydia, 9, tried unsuccessfully to visit the observation deck at the Empire State Building, which was still closed because of the blackout.
Undaunted, the children snapped photos of the building from sidewalk level while she considered other places for the family to visit.
"It's definitely not been the holiday we planned, but we've been very impressed with the plans that were put in place," Ms. Jackson said.
That's the kind of response from visitors that city officials were hoping for. Although officials said that it was too early to know the full impact on tourism, the blackout could scarcely have come at a worse time for an industry still trying to recover from the economic recession and the lingering effects of Sept. 11.
However, city tourism officials said that perhaps the blackout might have a different result than one might expect.
"What people outside of New York City could see about us reflected very positively on our mayor, on our leaders, but also on average New Yorkers," said Cristyne L. Nicholas, the chief executive of NYC & Company, the city's tourism office. "Those images of New Yorkers directing traffic and helping each other. Just like after 9/11, you had those horrible images being replayed, but there were also compassionate stories. There were compassionate stories after the blackout, and that helps the image of New Yorkers."
The blackout did not wear quite so well on some visitors. 
"We have another problem," Francesco Berardi, 38, of Bari, Italy, said. "Air France lost our luggage."
He and his friend Mauro Stasi, 24, arrived in the city shortly before the blackout and on Saturday were wearing New York T-shirts that they had bought for $10 apiece.
"It was a disaster," Mr. Berardi said. "One and half days we have no water, no light."
Power came back on Friday at the hotel where they are staying, and he expected his baggage to arrive last night.
"We decided to continue with our plans," said Mr. Berardi, who was walking south on Broadway, carrying a tourist book of Manhattan in Italian. "I have a plan with this book."
He was headed for the Empire State Building in case it might be open. If it wasn't, he said, he would walk around and maybe do some shopping.
Colleen Lewis, of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, standing in line for the matinee showing of "The Lion King" at the New Amsterdam Theater, saidthat she, too, continued her trip after the jarring first few hours of the blackout.
"We were going to Carmine's for dinner, and they weren't letting anyone in," she said. "They told us that we needed to find a place to go, because around Carmine's wasn't a good place to be after dark. It was really getting kind of scary.
"My first thought was, 'This would never happen in Cedar Rapids!' "

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: POLITICS; 
Blackout Is Testing Power Of Another Kind in Albany

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
The lights had not come back on in Midtown Manhattan on Friday morning when Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the State Assembly, announced that its Democrats would be holding hearings into what caused the blackout of 2003.
 It was a clear signal that the widespread power failure had catapulted the issue of electricity back to top of the political agenda here, nudging out of the way the fight last week between Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg over a financial aid package for New York City. 
 Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, has been at odds with Mr. Pataki over the deregulation of New York State's power system since the Pataki administration began the process in 1996. One reason is that Mr. Pataki achieved deregulation administratively, without the Legislature's approval. 
Mr. Silver left no doubt that he thought the blackout had exposed the weaknesses in the power system and that he intended to seize the opportunity to re-examine New York's regulation of the power industry.
"For almost a decade, experts have warned of a very real vulnerability that exists in the transmission and delivery of electricity throughout the state," the speaker said in a statement. "Despite attempts by the Assembly, through numerous public hearings, reports and legislation, to address this problem, little has been done."
The governor also seemed to recognize the politically explosive nature of the power issue today, as he toured the state urging residents to conserve energy. He immediately put some distance between the blackout and the policies of his administration, stressing that the problem seemed to have begun outside New York. He also adopted the role of the aggrieved customer, demanding answers as to why the cascade of power failures had occurred.
"There should never have been that instability in the grid that we saw across the Northeast yesterday," he said on Friday at an early-morning news conference. Later, Mr. Pataki joined the governors of New Jersey and Connecticut in calling on the federal energy secretary, Spencer Abraham, to investigate the cause of the huge failure.
Today, appearing at the Capitol with Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey and Mr. Abraham, Governor Pataki repeated his call for a full investigation.
In a separate interview, Mr. Pataki said that it was too soon to tell whether New York's relatively old transmission system played any role in the blackout, though he noted that so far no one investigating the failure had identified any problems with the state's power plants or transmission lines. He gently chastised politicians who, in his view, might use the fiasco to political advantage. 
"This is too important a problem to do anything like score political points," he said, adding, "I would hope those that try to politicize it just end up marginalized."
Yet, the governor said the blackout also appeared to be likely to revive debate in Albany on a host of related issues and bills. The Republican majority in the Senate immediately criticized the Democrats on Friday for not passing a Senate bill earlier this year that would regulate where power plants are built.
Proposals to build new transmission lines to carry power down the Hudson Valley to New York City, which have often faced resistance upstate, suddenly gained new life in the minds of some Republicans and Democrats. So did plans for new lines to feed power to Manhattan from New Jersey. The Pataki administration's efforts to promote renewable sources of electricity are also likely to get a boost.
And the squabble between New York and Connecticut over a cable that can carry power under the Long Island Sound promised to heat up, as Mr. Pataki persuaded federal authorities to order the Long Island Cross-Sound Cable to be temporarily energized to help areas recover from the blackout.
But the major battle in Albany is likely to be a partisan dispute over how much regulation is too much. Under the Pataki administration's deregulation plan, utilities sold off their power plants but held onto the network of lines that transmit the power from one city to another and into buildings. The power is produced and priced according to market forces.
But the companies that transmit the power are regulated by the State Public Service Commission, and would invest in new transmission lines only if rate increases were approved, something the commission has been reluctant to do, since the whole goal of deregulation is to reduce prices.
The Assembly Democrats argue that this system has led to too little investment in new transmission lines and other infrastructure for distributing power. Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko, the chairman of the energy committee, points out that the amount spent on new transmission lines dropped to $90 million in 1999, after deregulation, from $304 million in 1988, under a regulated system.
The result, he said, is an outdated, overtaxed delivery system with plenty of bottlenecks, the most serious being around New York City and Long Island. "It is a frail system at best," Mr. Tonko said.
But Senate Republicans say the attempt to use the blackout to reopen the debate over deregulation is a ruse, intended to distract attention from what they say is the Assembly's slowness to adopt a new law governing the building of power plants.
Senator James W. Wright, a Watertown Republican who is chairman the Senate Energy Committee, maintained that New York's infrastructure appeared to have performed well during the blackout.
Safety features throughout the state saved power plants from serious damage, and power was restored in little more than a day. Mr. Wright noted that the last two major blackouts, in 1965 and 1977, occurred under highly regulated systems.
"In fact, New York's infrastructure did what it was supposed to do," he said. "I don't see any correlation to deregulation."
A former chairwoman of the Public Service Commission, Maureen O. Helmer, acknowledged that the state needed to upgrade its transmission lines to get more power into the city. But she said the weaknesses in the national economy, the uncertainty in energy markets and the corporate scandals that rocked the energy sector have had a greater discouraging effect on investment than the regulatory system in New York. She added that the blackout may well prompt more interest in several stalled projects.
Some Democrats, however, said they thought Mr. Pataki should re-examine his commitment to free trade and take some actions to compel the utilities to build more transmission lines and improve the infrastructure throughout the state.
"We understand free trade," said Assemblyman Paul A. Tokasz, a Buffalo Democrat, "but quite frankly the public safety is at issue here."

HEADLINE: Newest Treatments Create a Quandary On Medicare Costs 

BYLINE:  By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
The federal Medicare program is expected to decide this week whether to pay for an aggressive and expensive lung operation that could offer a lifeline to tens of thousands of elderly patients.
 But health economists and medical experts say the treatment, however alluring, is part of an unsettling trend: new and ever pricier treatments for common medical conditions that are part and parcel of aging -- procedures that could potentially benefit tens of thousands of patients, at a total cost that would far exceed the kind of prescription drug benefit now being considered by Congress. 
 The questions, these experts say, are how much Medicare can or should pay, and whether cost-effectiveness should enter into the decisions.
The procedure under consideration this week is an operation for people with severe emphysema, whose lungs are so scarred that they are constantly out of breath. In keeping with its policies, the government's Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services has consulted with medical experts and professional societies and says it expects to issue its decision as early as tomorrow. 
The story of the operation, health economists say, is a case study of the troubling and thorny questions that Medicare administrators face as they try to live within the constraints of the $267.8 billion-a-year federal program.
Some say the operation can transform patients' lives.
"If your parents had this condition, you would seek this operation for them," said Dr. Joel Cooper, a lung surgeon at Washington University in St. Louis who developed the operation. Others point to a recent study indicating that its benefits are modest, at best. 
But all agree that the patients are severely ill, with no other options. And all agree that the operation is expensive. A recent analysis showed that patients who had the operation had medical bills averaging nearly $63,000 the first year, compared with $13,000 for similar patients who had not had it.
Estimates of the number of potential patients vary from 1 percent to 15 percent of the nation's two million emphysema patients, or as many as 300,000 people, at a total cost of $1 billion to $15 billion. 
For now, said Dr. Sean Tunis, the chief medical officer at the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, "nobody has a good estimate on how big this population of patients is."
Complicating the issue are other similarly expensive procedures that are on the horizon or have been approved recently. For example, Medicare is to decide next month on devices for patients with congestive heart failure, whose hearts are so damaged they can barely pump.
The devices, known as L.V.A.D.'s, for left ventricular assist devices, can help failing hearts pump. Dr. Annetine Gelijins and Dr. Alan Moscowitz of Columbia University, who did an economic analysis, said they expected about 5,000 Medicare patients a year to get the devices at first, but that as many as 60,000 have heart damage so severe that they might need them. 
At $60,000 per device, and with an additional $150,000 in hospitalization charges, the price for L.V.A.D.'s could range from $1.05 billion to $12.6 billion a year.
A recent clinical trial involving very sick people indicated that the devices were effective. But Dr. Alan Garber, a physician and economist at Stanford University, said the question was not whether they worked. 
"The big question is, 'In whom else does it work?' " he said. "The people in the trial had extraordinarily severe congestive heart failure and were being kept alive in intensive care units. That's the tip of the iceberg in congestive heart failure."
"We seem to be getting new technologies that are effective for common conditions, like congestive heart failure, like emphysema," he went on. "If you are talking about a treatment for a rare genetic disorder that affected 500 or even 1,000 patients a year it would not make much difference. But in the case of L.V.A.D.'s, or with lung volume reduction surgery, the potential number who will get it is quite large so it will force the issue. How are we going to make it available to Medicare beneficiaries without wrecking the Medicare budget?"
Dr. Tunis, of the Medicare services center, says he understood that the costs of new technologies can be staggering. But he adds that cost has traditionally not been a consideration in deciding what to cover.
"If the technology was effective, we would find a way to pay for it," he said. "There is no dollar value per life per year at which Medicare would decline to pay." 
But costs are mounting.
The agency just approved implantable defibrillators, which can shock a failing heart, preventing sudden death. They cost $30,000 per patient. 
Medicare restricted the devices to patients with specific patterns of disease, denying payment for them to about half of the million or more patients who could benefit, according to a large study. But now it is under intense pressure from doctors, patients and professional societies to expand its coverage to all those who met the study's criteria.
Then there are coated stents, tiny cages coated with drugs to prop open arteries and prevent the blood vessels from closing again. Each costs $3,200, compared withabout $1,000 for the older, uncoated stents.
The million patients a year who get stents typically get more than one, with some getting four or five, said Dr. David Hillis, an interventional cardiologist at the University of Texas Southwestern School of Medicine, who called the increased use of defibrillators and coated stents "a good way to bust the budget wide open."
Medical experts say that in addition to the legitimate costs of each of these procedures, they fear technology creep -- an increasing use of expensive procedures to wider and wider groups of patients, many of whom may not benefit and may even be harmed. 
"I think it is huge, I think it is pervasive. And it is a major driver in Medicare's cost growth," said Dr. Scott Ramsey, a health economist at the University of Washington who analyzed the cost of lung volume reduction surgery. "The reason Medicare is cutting payments to doctors is that its expenses for technology are expanding so fast." 
The emphysema operation, lung volume reduction surgery, sneaked up on Medicare about a decade ago.
Medicare never agreed to pay for the procedure. But unbeknownst to the agency, pay it did.
"None of the contractors in the Medicare system was aware that the operation was becoming more popular until it began being reported in journals," Dr. Tunis said.
In 1996, Medicare learned that it had paid for 3,000 patients and the numbers were growing fast. But there was a 17 percent mortality rate and no good evidence that the operation worked.
In response, the federal government started a clinical trial involving 1,218 patients. Medicare would pay for the operation only if patients participated in the trial, and if they joined the trial there was a 50 percent chance that they would be assigned to a control group that did not get the operation. 
Dr. Tunis says the outcome of the trial will determine whether Medicare will cover the operation. But Dr. Ramsey, the University of Washington health economist, said the agency never stopped to consider "what would happen if the trial came out with uncertain results."
The data, published in May, were not quite the ringing endorsement that many had hoped for.
The study found a subgroup that seemed to benefit -- patients with emphysema located mostly in the upper lobes of their lungs and little ability to exercise. They survived longer and could exercise more after they had the operation.
But that is not rigorous evidence, since any set of data will include small subgroups that benefit and others that are harmed. In evaluating trials of new drugs and procedures, the Food and Drug Administration does not accept such subgroup analyses, requiring a second trial for the subgroup that may benefit. 
But a second trial of the lung operation is unlikely, many medical experts said. The first one was so controversial that some doctors would not participate, saying it would be unfair to their patients to deny them the surgery if they fell into the control group. 
"We felt it was not possible for us to look a patient in the eye and say, 'We honestly don't know whether you are better off with this operation or without it,' " said Dr. Cooper of Washington University. He encouraged his Medicare patients to sue. "I went to court 28 times and won 28 cases," he said.
While some, like Dr. Ramsey, say that the clinical trial's results were far from a ringing endorsement of the operation, many lung surgeons disagree, saying that for the 25 percent of patients in the subgroup, the operation was a huge success.
Dr. Barry Make, who directs the emphysema program atthe National Jewish Medical and Research Center in Denver, was struck by the survival benefit in the subgroup. "That result is stupendous," Dr. Make said, adding that many patients also felt better.
Dr. Ramsey and others worry that if Medicare approves the operation for the restricted group of patients like those in the subgroup, technology creep may lead to many more having the surgery.
Seventy percent of the nation's estimated two million emphysema patients have upper lobe damage. How will Medicare know whether a particular patient also has poor exercise capacity?
Dr. Cooper says the solution is to restrict the operation to a few centers of excellence where experienced surgeons will assess patients and decide who should have the operation.
Dr. Tunis agreed but said there were limits to how much policing Medicare could do, or wanted to do.
"We don't have a direct way of enforcing compliance with coverage, particularly in patient selection criteria," he said. "It's sort of an honor system. But a lot of these patient characteristics are somewhat subjective or qualitative."
And that, says Dr. Garber, is almost guaranteed to lead to overuse.
There is pressure from patients, doctors and hospitals to cover expensive new procedures, even if their benefits are modest. And that is understandable, Dr. Garber said. "If you the patient are insulated against the cost consequences of your decision, why not get the latest and greatest?" But, he added, there is a price to be paid.
One solution would be to greatly increase Medicare's budget. But that would mean tax increases. Another would be for Medicare to consider cost-effectiveness, rather than just effectiveness. But, Dr. Tunis said, every time that has been proposed, the agency has had to back down. 
"This is the fundamental problem hidden behind the broader discussions of health care reform," Dr. Tunis said. "At the end of the day, somebody has to make the decisions one at a time about what people are going to get. But the reality is that we can't afford to pay for absolutely everything that provides some benefit."
So, Dr. Garber said, "Medicare is in a bind."
"The real question," he said, is "how can we inform the public better that, when they want to have access to health care, someone will pay and it will be them?"

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: THE NEIGHBORHOODS; 
For Owners of Stores Hit by Looters, Low Crime Rate During Crisis Is No Comfort

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WILSON

 BODY:
With the lights back on yesterday in New York City, several shopkeepers said they had returned to work to find their stores broken into and their merchandise gone. The police took reports of everything from precious stones to boxes of diapers snatched while the lights and alarms were out.
 A handful of reports of looting, which the police said appeared to be random and isolated, came after widespread praise of a an orderly, behaved New York during the blackout, which began shortly after 4 p.m. Thursday and lasted more than 24 hours in parts of the city. 
 The level of looting was economically insignificant compared with the huge loss during the 1977 blackout, from which areas like Bushwick, in Brooklyn, are only now recovering. 
But that was little consolation to the angry victims of 2003, who had written off to bad luck the business they lost and the perishables that spoiled, only to find themselves victims of their own neighbors and customers. 
On the high end, the police said that whoever was behind the rooftop break-in at Zodiac Jewelry, 2829 Third Avenue in the Bronx, got away with more than $100,000 in chains, bracelets, rings and whatever else had been in the display cases. 
A repairman at the store, near the intersection of Third and Willis Avenues, said yesterday that the burglars, benefiting from an alarm system rendered useless by the power failure, broke a hole in the roof and climbed down into the shop with a ladder. Perhaps worried the power would come back soon, they also cut the wires to the alarm and made off with the goods. "They left the ladder," said the repairman, who would not identify himself. 
A group of looters in Brooklyn left behind more than that: nine members of the group were arrested while robbing the Gastonia Grocery at 536 Ralph Avenue in Crown Heights, on Thursday night, the police said. 
Under the glow of a nearly full moon, neighbors saw several people climbing in and out of a hole in the wall behind the store, and called the authorities. But several others got away with most of what the store sold, said Luz Rios, 30, of Queens, who works there. 
"Money, cigarettes, MetroCards, groceries, beer, everything," she said. "They almost emptied the store." She said the group used hammers and other tools to smash the hole in the wall.
But the biggest blow came later. When the store employees saw the list of names of five men, two women and two teenage boys arrested outside the store, they recognized several. "They live around here," Ms. Rios said. "Some of them are from the next building. We know them. We service them. We give them service, you know? I don't know why they'd do that to us."
In other reports of looting, about 20 people were arrested late Thursday and charged with trying to steal sneakers from a Foot Locker on Flatbush Avenue in Flatbush, Brooklyn, the police said.
Six other people were arrested at a cellphone store and an appliance rental outlet in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and three more were caught trying to break into a jewelry store in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said.
The looters were gone by the time Fernando Batista, the owner of the Associated Supermarket at 938 East 163rd Street in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, arrived at the store on Friday morning. Mr. Batista, 60, whose pricier merchandise includes $5 jars of baby food, said there was a gaping hole in the roof. What had not been stolen was destroyed, he said, down to the eggs broken all over the floor. 
"They took all the baby merchandise, all the Pampers, all the baby formula," Mr. Batista said. "They broke my A.T.M. They took all my pharmaceuticals. They tried to break into the safe, and actually ruined it. They broke the cash registers, and they took all the overflow money in the office."
He, too, said the store was equipped with an alarm knocked out by the blackout. Mr. Batista estimated his cash losses at less than $10,000, but the broken equipment and inventory losses amounted to about $40,000, he said. The thieves had jumped through from the hole in the roof onto his dairy cooler, he said, denting it perhaps beyond repair. 
On the next block of 163d Street, would-be intruders were not so lucky. They managed only to damage the gate at Slam Dunk, a sports clothing store, before something scared them off, said an employee, Drame Moussa. "A policeman called the boss to let him know they tried to rob the store," Mr. Moussa said. "They said it was like 50 people, a lot of people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fernando Batista, owner of an Associated Supermarket in Hunts Point, under the hole where looters entered. (Photo by Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Street Smart And Built to a 'T' 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
TO the non-devotee who spots one, street rods are a diversion, a bit of whimsy on the blacktop. But to the owners devoted to these candy-colored, big-tired vehicles, they are a hobby that becomes a way of life. 
 Perhaps no one better understands the obsession than Mickey Lauria, a Wallingford businessman whose shop is known world wide for making "T-buckets" and selling the kits. 
 You may have seen a T-bucket; it looks like a Model T in the hands of a cartoonist. Men and women of a certain age caught their first glimpse of one on "77 Sunset Strip," the 1950's television show set in California featuring a character named Kookie. This may explain the strong dash of dune buggy in the car's design. 
Although the cars inspire serious devotion, their design says fun. People who buy customized assembled cars or make them from a kit aren't looking for transportation.
"It's an impulse buy," said Mr. Lauria, whose shop, Total Performance Inc., also makes other model replicas of cars from bygone eras. "You don't need one. You just want one."
For 31 years, Mr. Lauria has provided the means for indulgence, first selling parts for people restoring their own carsout of a shop in North Haven before moving to Wallingford and selling assembled cars, or the kits to make them. Last year, sales were "in the millions," he said.
Seventy percent of his customers assemble their own cars. The assembly manual is 134 pages long, but Mr. Lauria insists the car can be put together in a weekend (clearly by those adults whose childhood featured model-building rather than say, Hula-Hooping).
Ron Wcislo, a 50-year-old who worked in a Fairfield factory until his recent retirement, is one of Mr. Lauria's customers. He owns a T-bucket that he built for $12,000 and is now selling. He also owns a 1932 Model B coupe that has been featured in industry magazines.
The cars, he said, rarely fail to elicit smiles and thumbs-up signs from other drivers. He drives his car in parades and shows like the National Street Rod Association Show in Louisville, Ky., an event that draws 12,000 cars. Owning one, the Stratford resident said, means being part of a club.
"The camaraderie between street rodders is just great," he said. "If I'm on the road and someone needs help, I'll stop even if I have to turn around 20 miles to the next exit and they'd do the same for me."
Many of Mr. Lauria's customers travel to cruise nights at places like Bethel's Sycamore Drive-In, the Heavenly Donut in Seymour and the Mohegan Sun Casino. 
T-buckets may look as though they should be screaming down a race track, but appearances can be deceiving. These street rods are the vehicular equivalent of a silver tea service, polished to perfection but not for every day use. Owners favor sunny, dry conditions. They steer clear of busy parking lots and shun water like a cat. Because?
"Who wants to wash the thing?" Mr. Lauria said. "It takes a long time." An hour or two? "Try five or six." That's with the Q-tips for hard to reach places, air hoses to blow away dust, and hand-cleaning the engine. The bodies are molded Fiberglass. On certain models, the doors deliberately don't open necessitating a youthful hop to gain access. 
These days, Mr. Lauria ships and sells cars to such far-flung places as Malaysia, Japan and Amsterdam or just around the corner in Wallingford. His shop employs 22 people and is 8,000 square feet. He said he wants more space to expand the research and development aspect of the business. 
Dressed in a sweatshirt, jeans and cowboy boots, a cigarette never out of reach, Mr. Lauria, 62, would not be out of place working a wrench under the hood. Yet business keeps him more on the phone fielding orders or at the computer, checking his company's Web site, the one that enables you to build the car you might buy from him online, registering the price with each extra feature to complete a kit.
Routinely featured in auto magazines, Total Performance was also written up in People, Playboy and Penthouse magazines as well as showcased on television, Mr. Lauria said. 
He reports that hot rods (those vehicles used for racing and are not street legal) and street rods have "gone legit," and points out the name "hot rod" can be found in Webster's Dictionary. The street rod evolved because some drivers yearned for a legal hot rod.
"People said, 'I want a hot rod I can drive from point A to point B and go to a car show,"' Mr. Lauria said.
Hobbyist of all stripes won't be surprised to learn the cars are not inexpensive. The basic T-bucket kit of a basic chassis and body costs almost $4,000, but a kit-built car could easily cost between $25,000 and $35,000. A replica of a Model A or B costs as much as $50,000 complete.
Customers are an economicallydiverse group and mostly male, but women are becoming more frequent buyers. Ten years ago, two of Mr. Lauria's three daughters, Gina and Lisa, drove a T-bucket across the country to promote the business and "also for fun." Today his three young grandsons are frequent visitors to the shop.
Dave Goduti said it was assembling the car with his 17-year-old son that he most enjoyed. Mr. Goduti and David Jr., who live in Wallingford, built a Total T-bucket, bright yellow with white leather interior.
Mr. Goduti, a computer technician and his wife, Chicky, drive the car to cruise nights or shows, places they used to go as a family when the children were little, and talk with other owners. Street-rod owners are down to earth, he said, adding that something about the cars makes owners forget their differences.
"I guess it just brings out the good in people," he said. "It's your own creation. You put your own personality into it."

(Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Arts Institutions Suffer Growing Pains 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
ONLY two years ago, three major Hartford cultural institutions had big plans for renovation and expansion projects involving superstar architects. But two of the three projects -- at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art and the Connecticut Historical Society -- have been canceled, victims of a lackluster economy and the leadership's second-guessing of the original plans. Directors at the institutions say some form of renovation and expansion will go forward, but no specific plans have been made.
 The construction of a visitors center at the Mark Twain House, where the writer lived in the late 19th century, will be finished in November. Work on the grounds and renovation of other buildings on the premises must still be done. 
 The Wadsworth, founded in 1842, is the nation's oldest public art museum. It has the world's largest collection of Hudson River Schools paintings as well as holdings ranging from Old Master works to Sevres porcelain to Picasso paintings. 
In February 2001, the board choose an architect for its expansion and renovation: UN Studio, a Dutch architectural firm whose principal, Ben van Berkel, later became a finalist in the competition to rebuild the World Trade Center. Maya Lin, the Yale-trained artist and architect whose best-known work is the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, was enlisted to create a public art work on Main Street as part of the project.
The architectural plan was daring. It moved the museum's entrance from the crenellated facade on Main Street, steps from a bus stop where the city's working poor cluster for transportation, around the corner, across from an insurance company tower. Two spiraling staircases were to lead to new galleries.
The plan provided for an enclosed glass-walled concourse to span the entire museum, which consists of five contiguous buildings, each in different styles. A new cafe was to be built across from Hartford City Hall. A faceted, part-translucent, sky-lighted roof was to cover the whole structure.
The construction would have closed the Wadsworth for two years. An involved process of loaning art to other museums was begun.
Although some locals criticized the plan, it had plenty of support, particularly from the museum's then director, Kate M. Sellers, and the board, which consisted of some of the state's wealthiest and most influential people. Among them was its chairman, George David, chief executive officer of United Technologies Corporation.
About $62 million was raised. The amount was more than half the $120 million cost of the total project; $80 million was targeted for construction and $40 million budgeted for operating expenses and endowment. But Ms. Sellers resigned last October. Shortly after, infighting amongst board members led to the resignations of Mr. David and five other members.
Still, it appeared that the project would go forward.
But between January and March, while the board searched for a new director, it stopped making further commitments to the project, said the man ultimately chosen for the job, Willard Holmes, the former deputy director of the Whitney Museum of American Art. When Mr. Holmes was selected, in March, he expressed reservations about the plan, especially the closing of the museum during construction.
In an interview from Vienna where he is on vacation, Mr. Holmes, 54, said the board was reassessing the original plan in light of the fragile economy and the departures of board members, as well as staff members. It might be a better idea, he said, to "put less money into bricks and mortar and more into endowment."
He said the board was reconsidering whether the original plan was financially viable or adequately addressed space needs. He said he would not support any plan that closed the museum. Mr. Holmes dismissed the notion, proffered by naysayers, that the original proposal was overreaching for the Wadsworth and Hartford.
"It's certainly not being reconsidered because it is too ambitious," he said. "I didn't come to Hartford to be second rate." 
Meanwhile, the delay in the Wadsworth project comes when Adriaen's Landing, a $700 million hotel convention center, is under construction downtown. The Wadsworth is considered the gateway to the new center, which city and state officials hope will revitalize Hartford, Connecticut's poorest city.

A History Center
The historical society's project would have reinvented the hushed institution, which sits on a leafy street next to the University of Connecticut School of Law. The plan called for construction of a 115,000-square-foot interactive center for state history, near Trinity College. Frank Gehry, the architect noted for his curvilinear, titanium-swathed buildings, was paid $250,000 to produce a conceptual design, said the society's director, David M. Kahn.
The project was expected to solve the society's space problems; its holdings include three million documents and 30,000 objects, including the flag grasped by President Lincoln when he was assassinated. Society officials estimated the new center would cost $50 million to build, but would attract more than triple the number of visitors, currently 30,000 a year.
The plan had the support of Evan Dobelle, the dynamic former president of Trinity, who was trying to revitalize the college's neighborhood, which has long been besieged by crime and poverty. 
The idea was that the history center would be built in Rocky Ridge Park, on 13 acres of city-owned land.
Problems obtaining this land were surmounted. But then, in June 2001, Mr. Dobelle left Trinity to become president of the University of Hawaii. Mr. Kahn has identified Mr. Dobelle and Trinity as important partners in raising money for the history center. By early this month, the project's future was in doubt. The society is in transition, Mr. Kahn said in a telephone interview, declining to specifically discuss future plans. But, he added, "It is conceivable the location of the history center will change."
The architect could change as well, he said. A spokesman for Mr. Gehry's California firm said in an e-mail message, "We're not currently involved with the project in any way." 
So far, the society has raised $8 million for the new center; officials plan to announce a capital campaign. The group will also change its official name this fall, to the Connecticut Historical Society Museum, a switch suggested by consultants.
"We've learned historical societies do not resonate with consumers," said Aaron J. Wartner, the society's communications director.
Mr. Kahn said that before embarking on construction of the center, the society planned to formalize partnerships with other area historical institutions. He gave one example, Hartford's Old State House. He also said the society was continuing to study what a history center should be.
"We continue to work on different aspects of the undertaking," said Mr. Kahn, who listed a dozen other history centers built or under construction around the nation. "The Connecticut Historical Society can certainly scale up."

One Success
Dirt crumbles like cake underfoot around the hillside site for the Twain house's new visitors center, which is surrounded by fences. The center is between a former carriage house on the grounds and Hartford Public High School. The Twain house sits in a neighborhood once known as Nook Farm, a literary enclave that included the homes of Twain and Harriet Beecher Stowe.
Construction began in April on the center, which will cost $16.5 million. So far, $20 million in a $30 million capital campaign has been raised, almost half from public sources. 
Beyond the money for the center, the Twain board wants to add to its endowment, and complete three restoration projects: the servant's wing of the main house, the ground floor of the carriage house, and the grounds.
The new building will be 35,000 square feet, and was designed by Robert A.M. Stern, dean of the architecture school at Yale. It includes two galleries, a lecture hall, classrooms, a cafe and a gift shop.
Twain, whose contributions to American literature include "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," moved to the house in 1874. He hired Louis Comfort Tiffany to design the lavish interiors. But he would surely empathize with the budget constraints facing Hartford's cultural directors. He moved from his beloved homestead in 1891; he could no longer afford it.

COMPANY: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP (62%)
