HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: LOOKING BACK; 
In Calm Blackout, Views of Remade City

BYLINE:  By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
When the lights went out on Thursday, Imani Kuumba was in an eyeglass shop on 116th Street in Harlem. She was also in a very different New York from the one she lived in when the last major blackout in 1977 turned her South Bronx neighborhood into a harrowing zone of plunder and mayhem.
 In 1977, "it was complete chaos, just total chaos," Ms. Kuumba recalled. "They grabbed the flashlights and started looting." This time, the eyeglass-store owner and the other shopkeepers along 116th Street quickly ushered their customers onto the street and pulled down their iron gates. 
 The police showed up so fast, she said, "it was like they knew beforehand this was going to happen." And through the night, "the people took it in stride," she said. "They barbecued in the dark. They sang. They were listening to KISS and partying. I think they felt that this was just another event, something that occurs in New York, and it would be over soon." 
Tall buildings have crumbled in New York since the last blackout. Drug scourges have come and gone. The economy has boomed and flattened and struggled to boom again. Millions of people have moved out and in and changed the face of the city forever. 
Through it all, though, the blackout as metaphor for the civic psyche appears to have survived. And this time, Kenneth T. Jackson, the president of the New-York Historical Society, says he thinks it may be saying, "This is a city that seems to be under control."
In 1977, New York had reached an arson-scarred, drug-infested, economically challenged nadir. The blackout looting then was breathtakingly panoramic, often against a background of rock-throwing and flames. Today, the first snap of a blackout easily awakens fears of terrorist attacks. But this notwithstanding, Mr. Jackson said, "when we think of the city we think of theordered city."
The reasons for this are writ large -- a crime rate that in a development no one in 1977 would have been foolish enough to predict has plummeted to its lowest point in decades, with a third the murders of 1977; an economy that even after more than two years of trouble provides 600,000 more jobs than that of '77; and a population that thanks largely to a continuing transfusion of immigrants by the thousands tops eight million, or about a million more than at the time of the last blackout.
But the reasons are also writ small, in commonplaces of New York life that would have been unthinkable in 1977. For one thing, you can smell the roses, or at least the city parks' more varied assortment of flowers.
In innumerable locations they sprout unencumbered by the chicken wire that used to protect them from flower thieves, when they were grown at all.
In a growing number of neighborhoods, security-relaxed shopkeepers are not bothering to install the metal grating that has been a fixture of the urban street scene since the 60's.
In the subways, when a train bears the number 2 or the letter D, you can take it at its word. And when neighborhoods undergo change, it is often upward, at least economically. In the new hit musical "Avenue Q," a couple decide to leave their funky-with-good-feeling block for a fancier clime -- the Lower East Side, which may never before have been such an object of aspiration.
Thus, the near lack of untoward incidents during this blackout may reflect a lot. 
"We have worked over the years to build an infrastructure to protect this city, and provide services," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on his weekly radio program Friday morning. "Most of the time most of the things really do work, and that's why last night will go down as a safe night in New York City, a night where people got along."
Compared with 1977, he said, "I think you can make the case that people in New York City are happier, get along better, cooperate with one another." 
Those sentiments are widely shared, and for no small reason. The decade of the 70's was the time of the city's greatest population loss -- "the arch decade of white flight," in the words of John H. Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the City University Graduate Center, and also the first decade in which black and Puerto Rican middle-class families left the city along with whites.
A poll taken by The New York Times and CBS News just after the '77 blackout yielded this headline: "Nationwide Poll Finds 6% Think New York Is a Good Place to Live."
That was before an influx of young artists and professionals pushed the borders of gentrifying New York not only to the far eastern reaches of the Lower East Side, but also across the East River to such nonbrownstone Brooklyn neighborhoods as Williamsburg and even parts of Bushwick, the impoverished community most ravished during the last blackout.
At the time of the '77 blackout, the city routinely held auctions of the thousands of abandoned buildings and empty lots that it had seized in tax foreclosures. It was not unusual for an empty building in Bushwick or another poor neighborhood to sell for $25, to whoever wanted to take on the ultimate handyman's special in the company of packs of wild dogs.
Today, a growing working-class cluster of Ecuadoreans and other new immigrants are filling many of Bushwick's weathered three-story wood-frame homes, and Bushwick Avenue, in its heyday known as "Doctors' Row" for the occupants of its handsome brownstones, is beginning to buzz again. 
Meanwhile, houses and co-ops in the city's wealthier neighborhoods, along with those around the region, have risen more in value than homes in virtually any other part of the country. Last year, the city issued more permits to build single-family homes than in any year since 1985, although the long-term effect of steep property tax increases that went into effect in the city this year remains to be seen. 
That building boom has done much to account for a doubling in construction jobs since 1977 to more than 120,000. 
Tourism, which drew fewer than 17 million people to the city in 1977, is expected to attract twice that many this year, something that helped increase the number of service jobs in the city since '77 by well over half a million. 
The quiet of Thursday's blackout may well have little to do with any of this. The '77 blackout struck about 9:30 p.m. during a nasty heat wave, but this one came shortly after 4 p.m., with hours of daylight remaining. The Police Department -- with near-record numbers of officers -- had a chance to mobilize a visible presence in almost every corner of the city. By night, a cool breeze accompanied the dark.
Still, Dick Netzer, a professor emeritus at New York University's Wagner Graduate School of Public Service, said there was more to the calm than this. "I think it's a consequence of a much greater sense of some kind of empathy among New Yorkers for each other," he said, "and a sense that criminal acts are really wrong. I think there's a building sense of civility. It's such a difference."
He credited this to a generally prosperous decade, a tough policing policy developed during the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and "the social bonds coming out of 9/11." 
From the streets of poorer neighborhoods, even those like Harlem, which are now home to touchstones of prosperity like Old Navy and Starbucks, other reasons are offered for the peace. Among them are an overwhelming, debilitating poverty that has outlasted a near decade of prosperity, and Mr. Giuliani's extraordinarily successful campaign to cut welfare rolls, which have fallen by more than 50 percent from their 1977 totals of close to a million. 
"People are becoming accustomed to not having," said Ms. Kuumba, an administrative assistant with the city's Office of Children and Family Services. "They don't have it; the city's not giving it to them anymore; they're not going to have it and they never will. So come what may. There's just complacency."
The 2000 census, according to Professor Mollenkopf, counted 1.7 million New Yorkers living below the poverty line, which at the time was defined as an annual income of $17,603 for a family of four. Of these, a million were subsisting on half that or less, which Professor Mollenkopf said "is just about destitution, I would say." 
But in the new New York, even poverty has a different face. The huge population drop in the 70's -- an estimated 440,000 from the start of the decade until the '77 blackout -- left neighborhoods empty, burning and occupied in good numbers by people who did not have the wherewithal to get out. Along with the many struggling to hold things together, there were also the ranks of the looters who took over the streets of so many communities on the evening of July 13. 
Some streets, in neighborhoods like Brownsville in Brooklyn, can still take on that feel. But on most others, like many of those in Bushwick, immigration has brought variety, dogged hope and a feeling of greater safety. "If you compare New York's poorest neighborhoods with neighborhoods in cities like Detroit andChicago, they're not depopulating by and large," said Philip Kasinitz, chairman of the sociology department at the City University Graduate Center. "It means that even the poorest neighborhoods basically have a critical mass not just for city services, but for basic retailing."
From their windows, those people watch the street for trouble, and this, to some degree, helps crime fall. On Thursday night, Professor Kasinitz said, "people felt comfortable being out on the street." 
"Not just the young people drinking and looking for trouble," he said. "They were out, but so were a lot of others."

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: THE OVERVIEW; 
POWER RESTORED TO MIDWEST CITIES; PROBLEMS LINGER

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN and DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
Electric power was restored overnight and early this morning here in the last major metropolitan area to recover from the worst blackout in the nation's history, which left millions of people in the Northeast, the Midwest and parts of Canada sweating in the dark for up to two days.
 New York City's recovery from the short crisis leapt forward this morning with the revival of subway service to all five boroughs. "All New York City Transit subways are running on or close to schedule," the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced in a recorded message. 
 In Cleveland, city officials said water service as well as electricity were back up and running for 1.5 million people in northern Ohio, but city beaches along Lake Erie were closed because of a sewage backup caused by a shutdown at the treatment plant.
In Canada, Toronto and the rest of Ontario returned to near normal today, though with only 70 percent of its power capacity on line. Officials warned that there would be rolling blackouts for several more days to spread the load. 
Here in Detroit, an exultant Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick celebrated a second night free of looting and violence, as residents awoke to find refrigerators humming and fans spinning, two days earlier than expected. The main utility company, DTE Energy, said that all of its 2.1 million customers in southeast Michigan had power before dawn and that any remaining spotty power failures were due to routine problems, not the blackout.
Water remained scarce, however, as the vast system struggled to fill its pipes, and officials warned residents to continue boiling it before drinking or cooking, perhaps until Wednesday. Restaurants in suburban Macomb County were barred from opening today because of the water alert, though officials in other areas simply exhorted owners to boil all water used in cooking. 
There were a record 572 calls for emergency medical services overnight, most of them for people needing to refill oxygen tanks, but just 17 felony arrests, fewer than on a typical summer weekend. 
"Detroit is the model of the nation," Mr. Kilpatrick, who has struggled since he took office in 2002 to rehabilitate the reputation of a city known for crime and poverty, said at an 11 a.m. news conference on the steps of the police headquarters downtown. "This was the calmest city of all the cities that have been hit by this crisis. I believe Detroit now is a shining example of what can happen when all pull together."
Not yet 48 hours since the blackout, energy deregulation had already become the main focus of a previously scheduled National Governors Association meeting in Indianapolis, while utility executives and public officials continued to investigate and debate its causes.
In New York, where the lights went out on Broadway and everywhere else Thursday afternoon, all electricity was restored by 9:03 p.m. Friday, according to Consolidated Edison. The City Council estimated that the blackout would cost the city as much as $40 million in sales and income tax revenue, and that residents' collective income would drop at least $500 million because of decreased economic activity.
The return of subway and bus service, which carries seven million passengers on a normal weekday, was welcomed in a city where hundreds of thousands of people had been forced to camp out in Manhattan or take very long walks home on Thursday night.
Tito Montijo, 22, a handyman in an Upper East Side building, spent the blackout at work. Yesterday he was waiting for the A train at the West Fourth Street station, to go home and see his family for the first time since Thursday morning.
"I'm very happy the trains are running because I can go back to my wife and little ones," Mr. Montijo said.
In Detroit, as public officials declared the crisis over and excited residents snapped on lights and air-conditioners, the chief executive of DTE Energy, urged moderation, warning that the utility might not have enough power to meet demand.
The executive, Anthony F. Earley, suggested that appliances like air-conditioners, washing machines and pool filters not be used at least one more day, and said there would be rolling blackouts if customers did not continue conserving energy. "We are very tight," he said.
Later in the day, a utility spokesman, Len Singer, said that the demand had peaked at 3 p.m. at about 8,000 watts -- less than normal -- and that the system had been able to handle it without the use of rolling blackouts. Sunday is typically the lowest day of demand, and the utility said it was on track for normal operations by Monday.
The city of one million residents slowly blinked back to life overnight, after 36 hours of darkened, empty streets downtown and impromptu neighborhood barbecue parties in the sprawling neighborhoods. 
By midnight, 95 percent of the traffic lights were working normally, no longer flashing red. At 3:30 a.m., the buses began running, with special free service through Sunday night. The People Mover that ferries tourists and residents among downtown hotels and office buildings revved up at 10. 
"The whole block was screaming," Mary Moss, 53, said of the moment the power came back to her neighborhood in Northeast Detroit, "but I was in the house saying 'Thank you, Jesus.' "
Lawrence Birchfield, 55, a retired auto worker, heard his refrigerator rumble about 11 p.m. Friday.
"The first thing I did, I had a beer, I sure did," he said. "The second thing I did was take a shower." The third thing, Mr. Birchfield said, was to watch the ABC News program "Nightline," where talk of the blackout scared him more than did his own experience. 
"I'm going to go out and buy a radio with batteries and oil lamps," he said. "This could happen again."
By this morning, the serpentine lines at gas stations had disappeared, as the neon signs of fast-food restaurants flashed familiarly, and the cash registers at convenience stores rang anew. 
"It's really nice to have McDonald's open again," said Victor White, 74, a retired construction worker who has lived in Detroit for half a century, unfazed by the lack of coffee because of the water shortage. "This is where I have my breakfast every morning."
Mr. White said he was surprised the city had remained so calm. "It wasn't scary at all. Most people connected more than before, door to door, neighbor to neighbor. When the lights were on, nobody says nothing."
At 9:30 a.m., Tamara Thomas was already at C & B Beauty Supply, preparing for a salon appointment that was canceled yesterday, and a wedding this afternoon.
"I'm getting my hair done today," said Ms. Thomas, 25.
"And watching cartoons," interrupted her 6-year-old son, Brian, upset that he had missed even one episode of "Teen Titans."
The MGM Grand casino, which closed during the blackout for the first time since its July 1999 opening, had its 2,692 slot machines back on by 8 a.m., their bells ringing like clashing xylophones. 
"On a Friday, we have as many as 12,000 people," said J. D. Clayton, executive vice president of the casino. "We're happy to see them back."
Though the weekend's African cultural festival was canceled, the city zoo opened this morning as usual, along with the Michigan State Fair, whose Friday kickoff at the Detroit fairgrounds was postponed a day. In the suburbs, the Woodward Dream Cruise, a classic-car parade expected to bring two million people and millions of dollars to the region, was slowed but not stopped during the blackout, and was expected to return to full speed now that the traffic lights are back along the 16-mile route.
"Much in the same way that you can't cancel Christmas, we came to the conclusion that you can't cancel the cruise," said Bill Urich, the mayor of Royal Oak, a suburb two miles north of Detroit. "We're advising people to bring their own food and water, bring cash, bring a full tank of gas, to bring a lot of patience."
Even as the city delighted in its lamps, televisions, computers and other electronic devices, people continued to struggle with the shortage of water. Mr. Kilpatrick said this morning that 750 million gallons of water were pumping through the system, which normally carries 900 million, and that it would take awhile for the pipes to refill.
At the Detroit municipal airport, where the National Guard parked four 400-gallon tanks known as water buffaloes, hundreds flocked overnight carrying pitchers, buckets, coolers and even empty two-liter soda bottles. 
"When I got there it was so crowded I couldn't get any, it was crazy," said Natasha Dillard, 26, a waitress, who let her children, ages 3 and 5, use a dab from the sink to brush their teeth, a daily ritual they love. "They were outside playing. They kept saying they wanted water. It was terrible."
Ms. Dillard, who also works at Comerica Park, was suffering, too, from the cancellation of the big Aerosmith concert there Friday night. "I was planning on making $150 to $200," she said. 
 At a nearby CVS drugstore, Hosea Taylor, a retired music teacher, was buying five gallons of Poland Spring water. "For my cooking -- I didn't want to keep boiling it all," he explained. "I've been using Listerine to brush my teeth."
Mr. Taylor, 70, who got stuck in the subway during the 1965 blackout in New York, said he had learned from that experience not to panic, and had used the blackout to practice his saxophone, flute and clarinet. Fifty years after graduating from the University of Michigan, he said, he can still play the fight song on all three.
Though Detroit trailed the other blacked-out cities in the Northeast and Midwest in having its power restored, city officials said it had given them the opportunity to test the emergency operations systems, as well as the ability of citizens to pull together to improve not only the city's image but also the quality of life in its neighborhoods.
At what he said would be his final briefing on the blackout, Mr. Kilpatrick urged residents to continue conserving water and energy until both systems return to capacity.
"Get out of your house, go play, have fun -- we cannot have everybody overloading the system at once," he said. "If you are staying home, open your windows, spend some time outside." 
"Everyone is out today cleaning up the city for you," he added. "Go ahead and enjoy the parks. Just don't drink the water at the fountains."

SECTION: Section 10; Column 4; Job Market; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: For Many, Full-Time Work Means Part-Time Benefits 

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN

 BODY:
LIKE many new college graduates, Kellie Lee was thrilled when she finally got a serious job. It was actually her dream job, a position as an admissions counselor at an acting school and career center in Longwood, Fla. 
 "The owner had the most wonderful spirit," said Ms. Lee, 23, who lives in Orlando. 
 She quit three days later -- after she was told she would not be given any benefits by Ashley Camille's Modeling, Acting and Career Center, even though she was a full-time employee. 
"When I asked about benefits she said we would talk about the logistics when I got there," said Ms. Lee. "I expected to get them. If you're doing your job for the company, I feel that it's acceptable to ask for benefits." She added: "Healthcare, 401(k) -- I see what my parents are dealing with and they're stressed out over whether Social Security is going to exist for them. It's scary."
The school disputed Ms. Lee's account. Sonya Callender, the head of the school, said that it first gives benefits after employees have worked six months.
Growing numbers of job applicants are finding that positions with benefits are scarce. And unlike Ms. Lee, many young college graduates -- and even some older workers wishing to make career changes -- are taking jobs without health insurance or retirement plans because, they say, they cannot find anything with more security.
Andrew Nolin, 23, is another new employee without benefits. He took a full-time job last year at the Microtel Inns and Suites in Seneca Falls, N.Y., as a night auditor. He does not receive health or retirement benefits, he said. But, he added, "I had been looking for a job for a while and that was the first one that hired me." He said he has one more year before he will be removed from his parents' policy. After that, he doesn't know what he will do. "I am kind of worried, that's why I'm looking for another job right now," he said. "Hopefully, I won't get sick."
Employers say they are not happy to be cutting back on benefits. But faced with a sluggish economy and rising health care costs, they say they have little choice but to slash benefits packages, whether that means requiring a waiting period before benefits kick in, or offering no benefits at all.
Few employers were willing to speak publicly about any cutbacks they are making in employee benefits. But Bob Schleizer, executive vice president and chief financial officer of Xponential Inc., which runs a chain of 26 pawnshops in the Southeast, said his company had pared back. 
In the past, the company offered full benefits for full-time employees, plus stock options. But in 2001, the company went through financial difficulties, and last year the package changed. "We no longer offer benefits to anyone except full-time managerial staff," said Mr. Schleizer, who came as a turnaround specialist from Tatum CFO Partners. "Out of our 180 employees, only 40 are eligible for benefits." To partly offset the change, the company increased pay by about 50 cents an hour for employees no longer receiving benefits. 
Steven Rothberg, president and founder of CollegeRecruiter.com, in Minneapolis, said: "It's not a new strategy, but it's one that when the labor market is strong it wasn't used very much because in order to attract talented people, employees had to provide benefits. Now we're back to the old way, to a more traditional employment model: the power rests with the employer."
In the past, most companies offered benefits to their full-time, permanent employees, and it was only part-time workers or outside contractors who would be excluded. "Companies used to staff with freelancers who are flexible but don't get benefits," said Sara Horowitz, the founder of Working Today, which offers inexpensive insurance plans for freelancers and other independent contractors. "Now, companies are scaling back their benefits for their permanent work force making the distinction between freelancers and employees, in effect, meaningless." 
Still, many young people, at least, say they are not especially concerned by the shift. "One of the challenges if you're hiring entry-level folks, Generation X types, is they think they're going to live forever," said John W. Robinson IV, an employment lawyer with Fowler White Boggs Banker, a firm in Tampa, Fla. "They're not interested in a pension or even a substantial medical plan. They'd rather have cash."
"In our law firm, it wasn't as critical to entry level lawyers to get pension and other fringe benefits as it was to just get cash, in part because they had to pay student loans from school and law school," he said. "They said they would worry about pensions in 40 years."
That is how Kevin Lister feels. He was hired a year and half ago, when he was 25, at Mindbridge Software, outside of Philadelphia. Six months after he started working there he was given benefits. "I was unemployed for three or four months before I got the job and I was just happy to work," said Mr. Lister, who is now a sales executive there. "My mother was worried that I didn't get benefits, but that's her being a mother. I was just in a bad situation at that time -- I needed to get a job. Every job that I talked to there was a minimum of three months to get benefits anyway."
Scott Testa, the director of human resources at Mindbridge, said the 120-person software company generally hires employees right out of college without offering them benefits when they start.
"It sounds terrible, but it's kind of like a supply and demand," he said. Employees undergo a probationary period for six to nine months. After that, the company evaluates them, he said. "Benefits are expensive to the company and to the new hires benefits weren't important -- it was more important getting a job with a new company in a good industry," he said.
Job seekers determined to get benefits are most likely to find them at large companies. According to a 2002 study by the Kaiser Family Foundation, 99 percent of large companies, defined as those with 200 or more employees, offer health benefits. (A percentage unchanged from the year before.)
Only 61 percent of firms with 3 to 199 employees offered benefits in 2002, down from 67 percent in 2000. And a 2003 study by the Employer Benefit Research Institute found that 58 percent of full-time employees in medium to large businesses -- over 100 employees -- participate in an employee based retirement plan, compared with only 27.8 percent of small firms.
"Smaller firms have a hard time because of the rising costs of health care," said Carol Lachnit, the editor of Workforce Management, a magazine in Costa Mesa, Calif., about employment issues. "Bigger firms realize that you get better employees when you can offer them a more comprehensive package of salary and benefits, and it's important to them to make those benefits available to employees."
Some companies increase salaries "in an effort to soften the blow," said Robert Kneip, president and chief executive of the Oasis Group, a company in West Palm Beach, Fla., that provides professional services such as benefits management to other companies. "A lot of employees these days are making their own risk-benefit decisions -- do I really need benefits or is that as important to me as a higher wage or job flexibility? More companies are evaluating the costs of benefits and are being forced to cut back or eliminate their benefits programs."
"Firms don't like to eliminate benefits programs," he added. "I don't know of anybody who has happily or gladly or willingly cut back on benefits. It's a real unfortunate economic imperative."
Ms. Lee, for one, has not devised a plan for obtaining benefits once they run out; for now, she is on her parents' health insurance policy. "I am hoping to be a student forever so I'll get insurance," she said. "Otherwise, I don't know what I'll do."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Miami and Ohio State Deserved Each Other

BYLINE:  By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
WITH the college football season beginning this week, here is a promise: You will never again hear criticism from me about the Bowl Championship Series.
 I used to get all worked up when they discarded the traditional system of voting for a national champion after the major bowl games had been played. 
 My theory was: if it ain't broke, don't fix it. But they tinkered with it, and last season they came up with Miami and Ohio State. Perfect. 
The two teams played far into the night, going into double overtime in the Fiesta Bowl, before Ohio State finally won. Both universities showed they were masters of brutal power sweeps and intense masterminding -- and not just on the field.
In the months to come, Miami would throw at least two conferences into turmoil by pursuing even more dollars, while Ohio State would coddle its star running back, who then got into trouble off the field.
The B.C.S. produced two ultimate representatives of big-time college sports -- not that fans really want to fret about loyalty and ethics and academic purity.
After all, professional sports work just fine without paying lip service to such niceties.
Unfortunately, college football works us over with the aura of handsome old quadrangles, stacks of books, real students bustling to class. It trots out the odd physics major-linebacker with the 4.0 grade point average and intones the phrase "student-athlete" with smarmy regularity. So we tend to hold college football to its own standard. 
Then a Maryland football assistant is dismissed for handing over cash to a recruit, and they want us to believe this was some isolated act by a renegade, now unemployed. And in the wake of the terrible tragedy at Baylor, in which one basketball player is accused of killing another, the coach and the athletic director are forced out because of accusations of infractions in the program.
It makes you wonder: what is under all the other rocks?
Now it is mid-August and we need some comic relief from the grubby spectacles of Kobe Bryant's road trip and Ted Williams's heirs. And what do we get? The Terminator running for governor of California on his unspoken campaign slogan: "Don't worry, I was born in Austria, I can't be president." This is not the relief we had in mind.
Bring on the steroid set. Sacking and blitzing are looking better by the moment. Grimly compelling in its order and its violence, the National Football League does not formally arrive until the first week of September. But college football arrives Saturday, carrying the twin stigmas of greed and hypocrisy. 
Miami strutted its stuff by bolting from the Big East Conference, effective a year from now, to join the classy Atlantic Coast Conference.
To be sure, other universities have cut new deals in the past, decimating conferences or loyalties: Penn State, Notre Dame and the old Southwest Conference biggies. It is also true that Syracuse and Boston College would have followed Miami out the door, only to be disinvited by the A.C.C. in favor of Virginia Tech. But Miami was the instigator here.
Even more money is to be made from a championship game in the A.C.C., so Miami defected. The players are still not paid, the last time I heard. And nobody has ever convinced me what this campus-based brand of sports entertainment has to do with higher education.
Education was also the rationale for all the extra help given to Maurice Clarett, the talented running back at Ohio State. In an article last month in The New York Times, it was reported that Clarett was allowed to take oral exams after being unable to complete his written exam.
"I see some football players who probably should not be here, because their academic background is so wanting," said Paulette Pierce, the associate professor who was Clarett's teacher and is widely praised for her concern for her students. 
"So I say to myself, 'Do I keep shuttling them through the system, or do I try whatever it takes to get them to learn?' even if the methods I use may be seen as unorthodox." 
Thank goodness some teachers like Pierce respond to students whose skills are marginal. But most of us who went to college can recall trying to plead our case for some help or a better grade while our teacher was striding down a hallway.
At Ohio State, and other football schools, it seems as if the entire campus holds its collective breath while some teacher tries to help a prize athlete get through a course. 
And while Clarett was being tutored and pampered, he wound up in the public eye for allegedly exaggerating the contents of a car after he reported that it had been broken into. The National Collegiate Athletic Association is investigating what Clarett was doing with the car, registered to an auto dealership, in the first place.
Clarett is currently suspended while Ohio State prepares for its first game, on Aug. 30 against Washington (which recently canned its football coach for gambling in basketball pools, and lying about it). 
Even before Clarett was suspended, he had been skipping some team workouts. In a sport that preaches teamwork, his coach, Jim Tressel, looked admiringly at Clarett's muscles and said he seemed to be in fine shape, all on his own. 
The B.C.S. will have to go a long way to match last season's title game. One senses there are a lot of candidates out there.

HEADLINE: AROUND THE MAJORS; 
As Hitters Start to Produce, the White Sox Surge Into Contention

BYLINE:  By Jack Curry

 BODY:
General Manager Kenny Williams became annoyed when opening the daily statistics report and seeing his Chicago White Sox anchored near the bottom of many offensive categories, so he stopped doing it. He refused to check how the White Sox stood in the American League because he did not have to study the numbers to reinforce what his eyes had told him.
 "I already knew we're going to be 11th or 12th," Williams said, a terrible place to be lodged in a 14-team league. 
 But that was in June and early July. The White Sox have been streaking since the All-Star Game, scoring runs the way they were supposed to, winning games the way they were supposed to and hanging out near the top of the A.L. Central the way they were supposed to. Williams can study those stats again. 
As Williams explained how the White Sox had refined themselves from underachievers to postseason contenders, he did not initially mention the resurgence of Magglio Ordonez, Carlos Lee and Paul Konerko, the acquisitions of Carl Everett and Roberto Alomar or the sensational pitching of the 15-game winner Esteban Loaiza, the favorite for the A.L. Cy Young award. Instead, he focused on the obvious.
"We've scored more runs," Williams said. "It's really that simple. We didn't hit in the first half. Coming out of spring training, it was the one thing we didn't think we'd have to worry about."
Now the White Sox are worried about chasing the Kansas City Royals, something that they never envisioned in spring training, either. But that is one surprise they can handle. The White Sox have used one glorious month to rescue a season. Since the All-Star Game, they have averaged more than six runs a game, won 18 of 29 and scampered two games back of the Royals.
Once the White Sox started scoring, Williams got happier and Jerry Manuel, the manager who might have been one five-game losing streak away from being unemployed, got smarter. The changes in the first 28 games since the break could be attributed to Ordonez, who batted .390 with 5 homers and 21 runs batted in; Lee, with .345, 10 homers and 28 R.B.I.; and Konerko, who had been invisible with a .197 average and batted .333 with 7 homers and 24 R.B.I.
Even while the White Sox were sputtering, Williams made two acquisitions July 1, acquiring Alomar from the Mets and Everett from the Texas Rangers. Williams said he did several background checks on Everett, a combustible switch-hitting center fielder, and was confident he would play hard and blend in. Besides, the White Sox needed a hitter from the left side, as their lineup is stacked with right-handed hitters in Ordonez, Lee, Konerko and Frank Thomas. 
Because Williams and Alomar were teammates on the Toronto Blue Jays, Williams said he knew the man and always thought New York "was not a good fit for Robbie Alomar." Although Williams would not explain why he felt Alomar in New York was like sand in Vaseline, he believed he would bring energy at second base, a position polluted by D'Angelo Jimenez.
"Even at Robbie's worst," Williams said, "we were going to get better at that position." 
Williams prides himself on being direct and mentioned last month how he still had faith in the team's talent. But Williams quickly added that the White Sox needed to play better and do it in a hurry. Hint, hint. If the White Sox had not rallied, Manuel might have been out of a job. 
"That's not news," Williams said. "They all know that everybody is under review. The one thing about me is you don't have to guess how I'm feeling."
Right now, Williams feels good. He feels good enough to dream those October dreams, the kind of dreams that would have been laughable around the White Sox a month ago.
"One of the shortcomings of this organization is thinking that winning the division is the goal," Williams said. "It's not that way in the Bronx. It's not that way in Atlanta. We have to feel the same way. When it's all said and done and I'm not sitting in this chair anymore, you've either done it or you haven't. You've either won a world championship or you haven't.'

The $182,200 Start
As David Wells of the Yankees crouched on the mound to try to deal with severe back pain Monday night against the Royals, it was legitimate to wonder whether he would have been pitching in that condition if his 22nd start did not have a $182,200 incentive attached to it.
Wells has publicly stated how important it is for him to reach the incentive clauses that are attached to the number of starts he makes. 
When Wells pitched five and two-thirds innings of relief in a 17-inning victory over Detroit two months ago, he lobbied to be paid as if the outing counted as one of his start incentives.
Despite such a focus on an individual in a team sport, General Manager Brian Cashman said he did not believe Wells had risked hurting himself for $182,200. Cashman said Wells, 40, has been pitching at "less than 100 percent" for a long time and even skipped throwing sessions between starts to rest his back.
"I'm sure, personally speaking, he likes hitting the salary incentives," Cashman said. "But from a professional standpoint, you can't argue with the success."
Since the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, signed Wells to his creative contract before 2002, Wells is 31-10 with a 3.82 earned run average.

Unusual Expertise
If Mickey Hatcher ever loses his job as batting coach of the Anaheim Angels, he can find work as a personal batting practice pitcher for Jason Giambi or Hank Blalock.
Hatcher threw batting practice to both players at the All-Star Game. The American League fell behind the National League, 5-1, but then Giambi hammered a homer off Billy Wagner, a left-handed closer whose fastball reaches 100 miles an hour, and Blalock clubbed a two-run homer off Eric Gagne that proved to be the game-winning hit. Gagne has a 97-m.p.h. fastball and has not blown a save in the regular season since Aug. 28, 2002.
"We were joking with Mickey about it," Blalock said.
By the way, Blalock's homer looks even more monumental as Gagne continues rumbling through the N.L. like a locomotive. Gagne is 1-3 with a 1.48 E.R.A., has 40 saves in 40 chances and has permitted 10 runs while striking out 103 and walking 15 in 61 innings. Opponents are hitting .121.
After Blalock's run-scoring single off Mariano Rivera beat the Yankees last week, he was asked which moment was better: the single, or the homer off Gagne. Blalock was silent for several seconds. When a reporter mentioned that the hits were difficult to compare because the situations were contrasting, Blalock took the life preserver and agreed.

Chasing a Record
Other than Mike Piazza and his father, there is probably no one rooting harder for Piazza to break Carlton Fisk's record for homers by a catcher than the Mets' hierarchy. Piazza needs eight in the final six weeks of the season. If Piazza hits them, the Mets will feel more comfortable moving through the unnecessary soap opera of having him play games at first base next year.

A Sprinter Fades
It was fun for the Blue Jays while it lasted. The young, pitching-poor Jays stayed close to the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox in the American League East through July, but they do not have reliable starters beyond Roy Halladay and Kelvim Escobar and faded. After sprinting to a 46-34 start, the Jays have lost 28 of 43 and have dropped below .500 (61-62).
"I think in a year and a half we're going to be where we want to be," General Manager J. P. Ricciardi said. "I don't know if we'll be right there, but we're going to be a team that no one wants to play. If we had more pitching, we'd be right in the thick of it."

Dead, Tired
Phil Lesh has experienced countless long, strange trips in more than three decades as the bass player for the Grateful Dead. But Lesh, a rabid Yankees fan, has never made a short, normal trip to Yankee Stadium. When the Dead played at Jones Beach last weekend, the 63-year-old Lesh planned to do it at last. The plan was to play a show on Saturday night, see a game on Sunday and do another gig on Sunday night.
Who was Lesh kidding? Naturally, the Dead played a marathon show and Lesh was dead tired when the wake-up call came. He told Andrew Levy, a sports marketing agent who set up the tickets, that he hoped to see the Yankees another time. Levy countered with the postseason, because the Dead is not touring in October. But Lesh sighed and wondered about the possibility of that not-so-strange trip. "We're on the road so much," Lesh told Levy, "that when I'm home I like to stay home."

(Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Untangling Tongues

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO

 BODY:
HELEN DI runs a business of Babel.
 Every week, documents in dozens of languages pour into her Ardsley office to be translated into English. There are marriage licenses in Spanish, college transcripts in Arabic, high school diplomas in Chinese, witness accounts in Russian and birth certificates in Korean. 
 To her surprise, Ms. Di said, most of these requests come from Westchester customers who have found her company, DML Solutions, in the local telephone book. 
"We have been in the Yellow Pages for years," said Ms. Di, 45, "but even just a few years ago, there was no request from Westchester. Zero. None. Why this change? I think it's the growing number of immigrants in this county." 
Like DML Solutions, most of the other translation companies active in Westchester -- about a half-dozen in all -- say their profits have increased by at least 10 percent each year in the last three years despite the overall economic downturn affecting the region. The profit of DML Solutions, which was just under half a million dollars for 2002, has grown by 30 percent every year since 2000.
The 2000 census found 144,000 Hispanic residents in the county, a 67 percent increase from 1990. There were 41,000 Asians, almost a third more than a decade before. There has also been a diversification in the languages spoken in Westchester. While Japanese was indisputably the main Asian language spoken before 1990, now at least as many people speak Hindi or Chinese at home, according to the 2000 census. More Filipinos, Koreans and Pakistanis are also calling the county home. 
Responding to the changing demands, some Westchester companies advertise translations and interpretations in "all languages." 
Precise Translations, a Buchanan company owned by Gloria Mattia and her daughter Melissa Mattia, is one of them. 
What if the customer speaks a rare Chinese dialect, like Kejia Hua?
"We have it," Gloria Mattia declared. 
The company also offers Mandarin, Cantonese, Fujian Hua, Fuzhou Hua, Taishan, Shanghainese and a half-dozen other dialects that probably cover all of China, she said. "We have never encountered a request that we cannot accommodate," Melissa Mattia said. 
The older Ms. Mattia, born and raised in Argentina, came to the United States as a young woman in 1960 to study English. In 1976 she became the only Spanish interpreter at the Westchester County Court. 
"I handled everything, single-handedly, all the Spanish-language cases," she recalled. "But there were not many of them. Two cases a week at the most." 
Now the county court uses at least a dozen interpreters each day, court clerks say. In the recent death penalty trial of Dennis Alvarez Hernandez, a Honduran immigrant, the court deployed a half-dozen interpreters for witness testimony. 
"When I saw the increasing volume of Spanish cases," Gloria Mattia said, "I used to send them to my Hispanic friends. 'I cannot do this job. You do it.' Then I saw this business opportunity and opened a company." By 1999, when she left the county court, she had built up an extensive network of Spanish interpreters and translators, all freelancers. She assigns them projects at the county district attorney's office, social services agencies and legal aid groups. Her freelancers refer speakers of other languages -- often fellow members of translators' organizations -- to her company. 
While guarding the total number and the names of her freelancers as a trade secret, Ms. Mattia said that some of her translators of more obscure languages live in far-flung places like Lebanon and Ghana, receiving their assignments through the Internet.
Every translation agency charges different rates for different languages, and the prices are often a result of supply and demand. 
DML Solutions, for example, charges between 30 and 40 cents a word for translations into Spanish, Italian, Portuguese or German, Ms. Di said. Translations into any of the Slavic languages cost 35 to 45 cents per word, and translations into Russian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Arabic and Hebrew fetch 40 to 50 cents per word. 
For interpretation, Ms. Di asks around $100 per hour for most European languages and around $150 per hour for most Asian and Middle Eastern languages.
Not every translation business has prospered in the last decade. One example is the Japan America Learning Center, a company based in Scarsdale that specializes in Japanese lessons and translations. As more Japanese executives living in Westchester are recalled home by their companies because of the stagnant Japanese economy, the Japanese population in the county shrank to 6,700 in 2000, down by 27 percent from 1990, according to the census. 
Now, as fewer Japanese parents request interpreters for parent-teacher conferences at Westchester schools, the Japan America Learning Center has turned to book translations (of American financial tips into Japanese and Japanese fairy tales into English) to pick up the slack. 
"The last time we were in court?" said Kazuko Maeda, the owner and one of its translators, "That was two years ago. It was the divorce court." 
Ms. Di, who speaks both Cantonese and Mandarin, had worked as an English translator for a Chinese government agency before she came to the United States at age 27. Her husband, Daniel Zhu, had found a job as a translator at the United Nations headquarters. Later on, after they earning their business degrees in this country, they detoured into banking and consulting. Because of Mr. Zhu's reputation as a translator, multinational companies approached the couple for translation projects even before they started their own business six years ago.
"Daniel just loved translation," Ms. Di said. "We thought if you did what you loved, money would follow. But at the beginning, it was rather scary not to have regular paychecks coming in."
Now she or her husband rarely do the initial translation on any document, but they carefully edit Chinese translations they have assigned to freelancers. 
Until three years ago, large companies based outside Westchester were their sole customers, she said. Now clients include a mix of corporations, local nonprofit organizations and the county's recent immigrants. 
Their operation has also grown moresophisticated. When a translation project -- from English to another language -- is technical or complicated, she asks a partner living in the country where the language is spoken to proofread the draft. 
"Languages evolve, and we don't want to get any term wrong," she said. 
The couple has stringent requirements for their freelancers, most of whom are well-educated immigrants fluent in English.
Linguistic proficiency is far from enough. "He or she needs to have lived in this country for at least five years," Ms. Di said. "Cultural proficiency is a must." 
What about Americans who have learned foreign languages? 
"It's odd," she said. "But for some reason, I haven't encountered an American who can speak a foreign language as some foreigners can speak English."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Daniel Zhu and Helen Di, above, owners of DML Solutions, translate a document at their company in Ardsley. Their clients include a mix of corporations, local nonprofit organizations and the county's recent immigrants. (Photographs by Susan Stava for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
A New Restaurant Sets Cherry Grove Abuzz

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
ON Thursday nights on Fire Island, Cherry Grove bar-hoppers have their choice of nightspots where they can sip tall drinks while watching male dancers gyrate in g-strings a few feet away.
 There is Cherry's, an open-air restaurant-bar adjacent to the dock, where pornographic movie stars strut their stuff to disco music as a drag queen distributes their promotional photos. Across the wharf, a smaller al fresco spot called Sunsets on the Bay (slogan: "Where people come to play") offers "go-go boys" both live and on film. 
 With tourism down by approximately 20 percent this summer, and rentals fallen by about the same, the bars and restaurants of Cherry Grove, which lays claim to the title of America's first gay resort, have accelerated their promotional efforts. Tuesday evenings, the Grove Hotel features a trivia contest and free tacos, with activities emceed by a popular drag queen and on Wednesday nights, the place provides a grill and a chef for a barbecue promotion called "Bring Your Own Meat." Tuesday nights at Top of the Bay, another popular restaurant-bar, means free hot dogs. Its neighbor, Sunsets, competes with a free Chinese buffet. 
 "The list of bar events I publish is longer than ever," said Violet Silver, who puts out a nightlife guide called Violet's Wild Rose.
 Still, business is slow. Some say it's the soggy weather. Others point to the national economy and call it trickle-down. Many, however, trace the economic problems back two years, when Michael's, a popular casual restaurant burned to the ground The fire's cause was never determined.
 "There are two major institutions that used to be here, and they are not drawing people over any more," said Paul Jablonski, a real estate broker and part-time bartender at Top of the Bay. "There are a few shops and an art gallery, but most Cherry Grove businesses are bar-restaurants," said Mr. Jablonski, who is acting coordinator of the Cherry Grove Chamber of Commerce. 
 The loss of Michael's, situated at the foot of the dock and facing what's called Cherry Grove downtown, "was fairly devastating," Ms. Silver said. "The restaurant was at the center of town, and it was the center of the community. You sat outside and watched everything going on" in Cherry Grove. "When it disappeared, it left a hole in the community, economically," she said.
 For two summers, Michael's charred remains greeted visitors as they stepped off the ferry. Its acrid smell drifted across Cherry Grove's compact downtown long after the blaze was put out. "People saw that coming off the ferry, and it didn't have a positive effect," said Johnny Pool, a longtime Cherry Grove bartender who now works at Cherry's.
 This summer, visitors watched as a 2,300-square-foot building resembling a boat hull went up at the south end of the dock, the first commercial construction to go up in Cherry Grove in a generation. Priced at about $500,000, the structure is 30 feet wide and 50 feet long, constructed of log-like wooden blocks, and has exposed cantilevered girders. 
 "I think it's beautiful," Ms. Silver said. "But I hear some people say it looks like an airline hangar. They call it La Guardia on the Bay."
 Hal H. Hayes, a Fire Island resident and the building's architect, said speculation about the new restaurant was running rampant.
 "I have a lot of friends in Cherry Grove, and all I have to do is appear in Cherry Grove and I will be asked constantly about the building," Mr. Hayes said . "Everybody wants to know what it's going to be like. Everybody wants to know who is coming in."
 The building's location makes it a kind of symbol, Mr. Hayes said. "It's the first thing people see when they come in from the ferry," he said. "So the building has to present its best face to the bay, which it does."
Last week the Stein family, which owns the ferry service and formerly owned Michael's, ended the speculation. Ken Stein, 37, the president of Sayville Ferry Service, a fifth-generation family business, announced that the Steins had signed a contract with Ed Purcell, and that Mr. Purcell planned to open a restaurant in the new building next May.
 Mr. Purcell, who has worked in Cherry Grove restaurants for 17 years, said the restaurant would be named Mother's Place at Cherry Grove. It is his first restaurant.
 A resident of Farmingdale, Mr. Purcell worked at the Monster in the late 80's through early 90's, welcoming customers to a popular weekend brunch. He also worked at the local pizzeria, then spent several seasons as a manager at Michael's.
 Mr. Purcell said he planned to run the new restaurant much in the spirit of the old Michael's, where the menu was casual, prices moderate (at least by resort standards) and service unpretentious. "Michael's was a safe haven where everyone felt welcome, whether you lived in the Grove, were here for the day or whether you came over from the Pines or Ocean Bay Park," he said.
 Mr. Purcell said he hoped the restaurant, which will seat about 250 while the former one accommodated about 140, would also attract Nassau and Suffolk residents looking for a resort experience. "So many people on Long Island get in their cars and drive all day to a place like Cape Cod," he said. "Yet there is a wonderful resort just 20 minutes from them on Fire Island." 
 Mr. Purcell said he planned to draw from his experience at the front of Michael's in designing and developing the new venture. He said he planned an initial investment of at least $100,000, mainly in kitchen equipment.
 Breakfast and lunch would be simple, he said. "You can sip a cup of coffee, or eat steak and eggs, whatever you like," he said. Dinners might include a few more elaborate items. Mr. Purcell said he planned to hire an old friend, Kevin Schmitz, a chef and owner of the Marketplace in Great Barrington, Mass., as a consultant for the dinner trade.
 Mr. Pool, the bartender, said the new building, and the buzz it's generating, struck him as a good thing.
 "I think the new restaurant will draw business to the island, and that's what we need right now," Mr. Pool said. "Things have been a little slow and all the rain hasn't helped."
 Mr. Purcell said he was looking forward to opening next spring and had already selected an inspirational message a mentor had once impressed upon him: "Embrace what makes you different."
 "This place," Mr. Purcell said, "is going to go back to being what the Grove has been missing."

HEADLINE: Even in Online Age, Reunions Flourish 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA MORGENSTERN KATZ

 BODY:
DON'T tell the 1973 graduates of East Meadow High School that you can't go home again.
 They came back in little black dresses and suits and ties. Like girls and boys at their first school dance, they lingered in the hallway outside the ballroom of the Long Island Marriott in Uniondale on July 25, tentative about going inside. But once old friends began to recognize each other, the laughing and shrieking began. 
 It was their 30th reunion. Despite explosive growth in the last couple of years of Internet sites that help people reconnect online with those from their past, the traditional high school reunion is still going strong on Long Island. Nearly 200 people attended the East Meadow reunion, organized by Donna DeFilippis, a reunion planner who is president of Huntington-based Reunions of America. 
 That same night, Ms. DeFilippis had also organized a 25th reunion at the Woodbury Country Club for Northport High School and a 30th reunion at the Huntington Hilton for Brentwood High School, as well as two reunions at the Sheraton Hotel in Smithtown, a 20th for Copiague High School and a 10th for West Babylon High School. 
Elyse Richards and Jamie Bogenshutz were best friends in junior high school, stayed friendly at East Meadow High School and were among the first to arrive at the reunion. "I couldn't wait," Ms. Richards, who lives in Manhattan, said. "I wanted to see how everybody looks." 
 "Tonight is about memories and friendships from a very long time ago," said Ms. Bogenshutz, who lives in Massapequa.
 There is something special about reconnecting face to face, said Ms. DeFilippis, who has cornered the Long Island reunion market over the last 20 years, running about 100 high school reunions a year. She works with about 20 hotels and catering places on Long Island. She has 10 full-time employees who work in the office she runs from her home in Huntington and 40 part-timers.
 "No matter who you've talked to online or have been sharing e-mails with, when you walk in this door and you see these faces and feel that energy and get that hug and that kiss, there is nothing that can diminish that in any way," Ms. DeFilippis said. 
 The heads of reunion Web sites agreed. Classmates.com, with 35 million registered members, 1.8 million of whom are paying subscribers, was rated the fourth-largest site on the Internet for all online paid content. "You read about people online, their profiles, what they're doing, and it really gets you curious about what they look like today," said Michael Smith, the chief executive and president of Classmates Online, which runs the Web site. "You think, 'I'd really like to meet this person and talk to this person again after all these years."'
 Jeffrey Tinsley, chief executive and chairman of Reunion.com, said, "I think that more people are going to attend their reunions because we're helping keep them in closer communication." 
 After a year and a half of business, his site has 12 million registered members. "We're making it easier to find people for the sake of having a reunion," he said.
 Mr. Tinsley, 29, is an example of the benefit of attending: at his 10th reunion last year, he became reacquainted with a girl from high school and they are now married. 
 Ms. DeFilippis pays a fee to use a reunion Web site to advertise or track down classmates. The virtual reunion and the actual reunion complement each other, said Ms. DeFilippis, who is a graduate of Walt Whitman High School in Huntington, class of 1976. Once people receive her invitation, they often go to the Internet to see who signed up. 
 William Chancellor, of Oakdale, who was on the East Meadow wrestling team, said he checked the Web sites after he got the invitation and then e-mailed seven former teammates. Others at the reunion, like Jeremy Boss of Atlanta and Marc Sonenshein of Florida, said they had checked Classmates.com, too.
 They were not alone in traveling from afar. Elaine Timmerman Neumeyer came from the North Georgia mountains and said the funniest thing about this reunion was the eyeglasses. "It's a riot, because everybody has them now, but no one will wear them," she said. "My friend keeps asking me to read all the nametags to her." 
 Ms. DeFilippis said the number of graduates who travel for reunions is down about 10 percent since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, although she said that the weak economy might also have had an effect. 
 For some East Meadow graduates, there were pleasant surprises. Jill Pomerantz of Sands Point said it was great to see her sixth-grade boyfriend again. Linda Peskin Roslow of Merrick met an old friend who told her a funny story about her father. That "made her night," she said; because her father died 15 years ago, she treasured the remembrance. 
 This is an important function of reunions, said Gail Satler, an associate professor of sociology at Hofstra. Graduation from high school marked the end of a phase when community and family were intact. "Once high school is over, people go their separate ways," she said; if that was a happy time, going back creates feelings of security and nostalgia. 
 The people working the reunion help generate nostalgia. Reunions of America hands out a directory at each reunion listing tidbits from the year of graduation. (Average cost of a home in 1973: $32,500.) The disc jockey threw out trivia questions: "Who sang backup vocals on Carly Simon's 'You're So Vain'?" (Mick Jagger.) 
 It feels good to reconnect with people who shared a maturing process, said Joseph Scardapane, director of the psychology clinic at Hofstra.
 "In no other period of your life are you developing so rapidly and doing so many things for the first time," he said, like the first intimate relationship, the first job, the first driving experience. "That period of life is very intense emotionally," he said, although, it is illusory to think people can relive it. 
 And, Dr. Satler said, "You either loved that time, or it was the most miserable time of your life." If you felt like an outsider, she asked, "why would you go back?" Some, she conceded, go back for closure, but she surmised that it's mostly those who were popular who return. 
 Not so, Ms. DeFilippis, who is 45, said. "People really worry about coming," she said. "They think nobody's going to remember them or think of them fondly." 
 But, she added, many people call her the next day and say: "I didn't realize how well people thought of me. I didn't realize how many people knew me."

HEADLINE: About That Glass Ceiling: Look at Specific Women 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I was a bit perplexed by "Reflections on a Glass Ceiling: Why Women Still Struggle to Get Ahead in State Politics" (front page, Aug. 10). 
The failure of certain women to rise in the political hierarchy is not an indictment of our system in New Jersey, but perhaps more a "reflection" on the specific individuals you mention. Our previous governor was a woman, and numerous women have served in Congress who were leaders in the state -- among them, Florence Dwyer, Millicent Fenwick and Marge Roukema. I had the honor of serving as Ms. Fenwick's chief of staff and as her campaign manager in her unsuccessful race for the United States Senate. Her defeat had more to do with a 10 percent unemployment rate than her gender. 
 As for Nia Gill, I have the misfortune of living in her Senate district. I recently wrote her a letter asking her opinion of Amiri Baraka's hateful poem. It took her more than three months to respond (and only after I sent a second letter and copied the local paper) and she refused to take a position on this issue, citing, unbelievably, support for Mr. Baraka among Jews. Maybe this, and not her gender, is why Ms. Gill was shunned by her party and will be stymied in her efforts to move ahead.

Lawrence Rosenshein
Montclair

HEADLINE: As American As Baseball 

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
 I am disappointed in William C. Rhoden's column ("The Trade Deadline Should Pass," Aug. 4) calling for the restriction or elimination of trading during the baseball season. His comments show an unfamiliarity with the appeal of baseball, and he reduces his credibility with calumny. 
 Baseball's relatively high number of in-season trades represents a huge part of the game's appeal and a way to maintain competitive balance. Ardent fans clog sports radio phone lines to discuss and dissect potential deals, and they flock to sports Web sites to read the latest rumors of trades. Most industries would kill to find such an easy way to get customers talking about their products, and indeed, no other sport can match the free publicity that baseball gets from its trades.
Furthermore, allowing teams to trade during the season does not facilitate or encourage "surrender," as Rhoden mistakenly calls these maneuvers.
Instead, it allows noncontending teams to trade away a few extra victories in the current season for the prospect of significantly more down the road. This trade-off is a smart baseball strategy that has been a part of the game for its entire history, and it rewards the organizations that can correctly evaluate their own talent base.
Finally, Rhoden twice calls in-season baseball trades "un-American." Nothing could be further from the truth. The United States is one of the world's most free economies, whose industries are, relative to the rest of the world, unfettered by excessive restraints and regulations.
Any further regulation of in-season trading would be more reminiscent of the command economies of Lenin and Mao than of the laissez-faire approach of the United States. It would appear that in trying to vilify baseball's open trading policies, Rhoden has been caught off base.

KEITH LAW
Toronto

The writer is special assistant to the general manager of the Toronto Blue Jays.

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK; 
New Business Plan's Objective: Being Mom

BYLINE:  By Lisa Belkin

 BODY:
SOMETIMES an epiphany can look a lot like a nervous breakdown. Such was the situation for Gail Wiggin earlier this summer when she realized that her son was not going to slide into college while she worked her usual 60-hour weeks.
 Although I have never actually met Ms. Wiggin, we've had a continuing e-mail conversation for a few years now. Her two children are about five years ahead of both of mine, and her notes are like travel advisories from the front lines full of wry advice on how to work and raise two teenagers (her son, Teke, is 17, and her daughter, Amary, is 15). 
 Which is why her latest news has me in a cold sweat. Ms. Wiggin and her husband, Alec, run their own company, aabalone, which is in the brand building business. Her recent turmoil began during a pitch to a core client. As she describes it, the 50-something company chairman nodded enthusiastically through the pitch, while the not-quite-30-something assistant sat and glared.
 When the chairman left the assistant to close the deal she "verbally pounced" on Ms. Wiggin, who is 53 and became suddenly fed up with being hectored by "youngsters who think they know everything because they are young and think I know nothing because I'm not."
 So Ms. Wiggin dropped the client, which was either a very brave or very stupid thing to do in this economy, and took a new look at the life she had more or less ignored over the last few years. "Bills were piling up along with the dust balls, wet sports clothes, unstrung rackets and interminable unfilled-out school forms," she says. "Plus, there was never any food in the house other than left-over pizza and impossibly moldy bread. The bed linen hadn't been changed since May."
 What worried her most, she says, was that this chaos had seeped into her son's quest for college. She herself had sent him to his winter College Boards two hours late. A scouting trip organized by Mr. Wiggin had been a nonstarter, because neither husband nor son had thought to call the prospective college first, and had arrived when the school was all but closed for the summer.
 "Do kids get into college by accident?" she wondered. "These people need a mom."
 So she became one, and she was e-mailing me to report that all those years of competing and obsessing in the workplace were perfect training for her new role. She had spent a career thinking that work was preparing her to do even more work. Who knew that what she was really learning was something else entirely?
 "Made the plane, hotel and California-appropriate convertible car rental reservation," she wrote of the first leg of her campaign. "Identified the seven target colleges. Dove deeply into their Web sites. Interviewed own son as to his academic interests (hey, I've been working and have to catch up on a few things) and targeted professors at each of the colleges in his strongest academic interest area."
 She went on to set up tours and interviews at each school. Then she "harangued" her son into "composing a letter to target professors, detailing his arrival on campus and requesting a face-to-face meeting." Since she would not actually be going on the trip -- it was to be a bonding experience for father and son -- Ms. Wiggin decided that they would need to communicate with home base "so all California Starbucks locations with wireless technology near our target colleges were located and plotted on maps via MapQuest."
 Just before the trip began early this month Ms. Wiggin put the final touches on her presentation. Each traveler received a kit containing folders for each college with driving directions, admissions building map, pertinent college data, areas of academic excellence, bios of each teacher who had agreed to meet with Teke, and, natch, the Starbucks map.
 There was also an R.B.F.I. folder (Read Before First Interview). "I am particularly proud of my sons R.B.F.I.," Ms. Wiggin says. "In it were documents like 'Questions to Ask the College Guide During the Tour,' 'Questions Which Might Be Posed During the College Interview' and 'What to Look for When Visiting a Campus.' "
 When Ms. Wiggin and I last spoke, the California trip had just begun, and so far neither of her "guys" had gotten lost or left their computer charger or contact lens case in a motel room (as per a checklist she included). Flush with success, Ms. Wiggin was turning to her next projects for the summer -- planning the second trip of the college campaign and rethinking the direction of her business.
 "What do you think," she asked, "is this college thing an income producing business model?"
