HEADLINE: Most Big U.S. Airlines Ease Policy on Nonrefundable Tickets 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Travelers often say that the big airlines are as responsive to their complaints as a block of concrete. But this week, some airlines are rolling back to a degree a stringent use-it-or-lose-it policy on nonrefundable tickets that they put in place last fall to nudge business travelers toward buying higher-priced refundable tickets.
 On Tuesday, American Airlines, the world's largest carrier, said it would allow a passenger to apply the full value of a nonrefundable ticket to a future ticket if the passenger called in to cancel a flight before the plane's departure. The passenger will have one year from the date the original ticket was issued to apply the value of the ticket to the new flight. The passenger will also have to pay a change fee that usually amounts to $100 for domestic flights and up to $200 for international flights. 
 Continental Airlines followed American's lead on Wednesday. Delta Air Lines said yesterday morning that it was also adopting the policy. Northwest Airlines went one step further and said yesterday that travelers could still keep the value of their original ticket for a year from the departure date even if they did not call in advance to cancel a flight.
The new policy is more generous than one that the airlines had put in place in the fall of 2002. Under those rules, passengers canceling a flight had to book a new flight by the departure date of their original flight or they lost the value of the ticket.
Except for Northwest, the policy being adopted this week is not nearly as consumer-friendly as one that was in place before the fall of 2002. Under the old rule, passengers could retain the value of their nonrefundable ticket for a year even if they did not call in to cancel a flight.
When the airlines went from that lenient policy to the hard-edged one, they were flooded with complaints, especially from business travelers.
Tim Wagner, a spokesman for American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said the company received complaints "frequently." He said passengers canceling flights often did not know when they would travel next and chafed at the fact that they were required to book another flight before the original departure date.
As of mid-afternoon yesterday, two major airlines had not followed American, Continental, Northwest and Delta. The holdouts were US Airways, the carrier that first announced the use-it-or-lose-it policy, and its code-sharing partner, United Airlines, a unit of UAL, which said it had no plans to match the new refund policies. In August 2002, the same month it filed for bankruptcy protection, US Airways said it was imposing the stringent policy on tickets for travel starting in the fall. The other major hub-and-spoke airlines quickly matched its move.
During the economic slump, business travelers have been turning away from buying expensive, last-minute tickets and gravitating toward nonrefundable tickets with greater restrictions and change fees. The imposition of the tougher policies last fall was intended to discourage business travelers from buying the cheaper tickets, though there are no signs that has worked.
Airlines have been sharply cutting back on passenger service since the recent economic slump and the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. They have tried eliminating hot meals on domestic flights, charging travelers to fly standby and charging for overweight or oversized baggage that would have been loaded on the plane free a couple of years ago. The new standby fees were watered down or eliminated when passengers and consumer advocates railed against the airlines.
The constant changing of consumer policies has become one of the greatest indicators of the increasing desperation of the airlines as they struggle to make a profit during the industry's worst financial downturn.
"We're rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic," said Joe Brancatelli, an Internet travel columnist and advocate for business travelers. "This is what the airlines always do."
Mr. Brancatelli said the confusion of the airlines over how to treat nonrefundable tickets pointed to a larger problem with the fare structure. Airlines should treat tickets and seats as if they are commodities that passengers own once they are bought, he said. This means that travelers would be able to do anything they want with the tickets once they are bought, including reselling them or giving them away. It also means passengers would not get to reapply the value of their tickets to a future flight if they cancel their original flight.
Theaters and sports stadiums operate on that model, he said, so why not airlines?

HEADLINE: Prized Metal Is in Slump But Nickel Is Surging 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
Sagging demand in North America and Europe has led to fierce price-cutting of stainless steel, a metal prized for its resistance to corrosion, its bright appearance and its easily cleaned surfaces.
 "The market in North America is about as weak as we've seen it in 25 years," said Joseph Gibbons, chief executive of Great Plains Stainless Inc. of Tulsa, Okla., which trades stainless steels used in breweries, slaughterhouses and other industrial plants. Investment in equipment has fallen in the last three years, lowering demand for raw materials. According to American Metal Market, a trade publication, the price of one widely used type of stainless steel bar has sunk 16 percent in the last year. The prices of cold-rolled sheet, used for appliances, have fallen 3 percent to 4 percent. 
 Yet as producers of stainless steel battle for sales, the price of nickel, one of its main ingredients, is surging. The London Metal Exchange's three-month nickel contract traded around $9,575 a metric ton today, up 70 percent since early January 2002 and 33 percent so far this year. Prices of stainless steel scrap, an alternative raw material source, have also climbed.
But with stainless steel making up about three-quarters of nickel consumption, the question is how long prices of the two materials can keep moving in opposite directions.
Echoing many other analysts, Daniel A. Roling of Merrill Lynch in New York, said he expected the nickel price to remain strong for at least the next three years.
The nickel market's most recent lift has come from a continuing strike at the Sudbury, Ontario, operations of Inco Ltd., the Western world's biggest nickel producer. The strike, which began June 1 amid a dispute over pensions and health care benefits, has idled about 9 percent of Western production capacity. Inco's global operations account for 19 percent of the world's nickel supplies and 26 percent of supplies for the Western world.
But the surge in nickel prices also reflects fears of a looming and long-lasting supply squeeze. The shortage stems in part from three projects in western Australia that came onstream in the late 1990's using a new extraction process known as high-pressure acid leaching. The technology has turned out to be a disappointment, with both production and costs missing their targets.
Robert Way, principal base metals analyst at the Sydney office of AME Mineral Economics, an independent research concern, said that the prospect of rising production from these projects had discouraged other nickel producers from moving ahead with new mines. "A deficit has opened up and it's going to stay that way," Mr. Way said in a recent phone interview. Two big Inco projects, one at Voisey's Bay in Labrador and another at Goro in the French territory of New Caledonia, are not scheduled tostart production before 2006.
Inco, which is based in Toronto, suspended construction work at Goro last December after the projected cost of the project jumped as much as 40 percent, to $2.1 billion. The company said last week that it had identified savings of $225 million, but that further cost cuts and financial assistance from the French government were still needed for the mine to go ahead. The Voisey's Bay project is proceeding on schedule.
Anticipating a supply shortfall, nickel producers' stock prices have risen sharply in recent months -- even Inco's, which are up 23 percent since the strike began, closing at $25.14 in New York today.
But the share prices of stainless steel producers have been languishing, as the companies remain caught between spiraling costs and slumping demand. Besides higher nickel prices, they have complained of rising energy costs and adverse currency movements.
Slater Steel Inc., which is based in Mississauga, Ontario, and has mills in the United States and Canada, sought protection from creditors earlier this summer and warned last week of a heavy second-quarter loss. Slater said it would have to write down the value of its stainless steel inventory to reflect "manufactured costs in excess of net realizable values." The industry rule of thumb, said Mr. Gibbons of Great Plains Stainless, is that profits shrink by 5 percent for every 1 percent drop in volume.
Demand in Europe for stainless steel has also shrunk in recent months. Markus A. Moll, senior analyst at SMR -- Steel and Metals Market Research of Reutte, Austria, estimates that European stainless steel mills have cut third-quarter production by about 10 percent by extending summer maintenance shutdowns. Furthermore, Mr. Moll said in an e-mail message, many mills have indicated they will trim nickel purchases for the rest of the year.
Demand for nickel has so far been buoyed by a torrent of new stainless steel mills around the world, with new capacity of more than three million metric tons in 2002 and 2003 combined. North American Stainless, a unit of Acerinox S.A. of Spain, for instance, started up a big new hot rolling mill in Carrollton, Ky., in May.
In addition, demand has remained strong in Asia, especially in China, which in 2001 became the world's biggest stainless steel user, overtaking the United States and Japan.
China still imports about three-quarters of its stainless steel needs. Scott Hand, Inco's chairman, recently told analysts that the company expected Chinese consumption to keep growing 10 percent to 20 percent a year until at least 2006.
Still, Mr. Moll said that both nickel and stainless steel markets could be in for "a bumpy ride" over the next few months. Even China "will have a year of consolidation," he said.
Richard M. Ubinger, chief financial officer of Universal Stainless and Alloy Products Inc. of Bridgeville, Pa., said he saw no sign for now of a sustainable improvement in the stainless steel market. Universal, a relatively small producer, reported a second-quarter loss, and revenues that were down 21 percent from the period a year earlier.
But many analysts, including Mr. Moll, say prospects should brighten in 2004. They cite low inventories and the expectation that demand from the construction and automotive industries will rise as the American and European economies accelerate.
Should these forecasts prove correct, by next summer stainless steel and nickel prices could be moving in the same direction: up.

HEADLINE: Pubs Make Coziest of Investment Targets 

BYLINE:  By HEATHER TIMMONS

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
In Europe this year, some of the most frenzied deal-making is centered around one of the oldest and once stodgiest of institutions, the British pub.
 On Friday, the British beer producer Scottish & Newcastle is expected to receive at least five bids for its 1,500 pubs, which include those under the Rat and Parrot and T&J Bernard names. Analysts value the chain at about $:2.5 billion ($4 billion). 
 The deal, expected to close by the end of the year, could be followed quickly by several others, analysts say, as the pub business continues a consolidation wave that began a decade ago. Traditionally, beer brewers have owned the pubs in Britain, and would serve only their own brews. 
A decade ago, the Beer Orders, a government rule, forced brewers with more than 2,000 pubs to sell them off, to prevent the dominant beer producers from remaining the dominant distributors. The law cut the beer industry in half, with most players opting to become either a brewer or a pub owner. Scottish & Newcastle, falling under the 2,000-pub limit, is among the last brewers to sell its pubs.
A string of deals since then, however, has left the pub side dominated by big chains. The 10 largest companies now own 43 percent of the country's pubs, Standard & Poor's reports.
The Scottish & Newcastle deal is attracting attention from more than just its retail competitors. Along with pub chains including Pubmaster, Mitchells & Butlers and the Laurel Pub Company, interested bidders include the private equity groups BC Partners, CVC Capital Partners and Cinven, and property investors including David and Simon Reuben, and Hugh Osmond, as well as the French bank Paribas.
BC Partners has banded with Pubmaster. But as of this evening, how the rest of the parties would align themselves remained in flux. "Everyone is talking to everyone else," said one person close to the negotiations. "This is the most extraordinary situation I've ever seen."
If Mitchells & Butlers is not the winning bidder for Scottish & Newcastle, Mitchells itself could be the next to succumb to consolidation, analysts said. Mitchells & Butlers, a 2,105-pub chain, rebuffed two buyout offers this spring.
British pubs are naturally attractive to investors because of their steady revenue streams. In Britain, about 65 percent of beer is consumed outside the home, compared with only about 25 percent in the United States. Many Britons have a "local," a pub around the corner from their home or office, that is a regular stop after work, on a weekend or even at lunchtime. Laws dating back to World War I, intended to make sure that factory workers put in a full day, force them to close at 11 p.m., but while open, they draw a constant stream of patrons.
"People drink in a good and bad economy," Peter Hansen, president of P.C. Hansen & Company, a corporate finance adviser to the industry based in London. "It is not a recession-sensitive industry." 
The overall numbers are staggering. Britain is home to about 65,000 pubs, with sales of $:23.3 billion ($37 billion) in 2001, according to the Mintel International Group, a consulting firm. A direct American comparison is hard to come by because most bars in the United States are individually owned and so do not report sales. But as a guideline, that 2001 figure for British pubs nearly matched the $40.6 billion generated that year by all McDonald's restaurants worldwide including franchises and joint ventures. 
Besides their sales streams, the business potential of pubs has drawn investors. British pubs have moved away from their smoky, sleepy roots; many owners have opted to replace brass lamps, carpet and flocked wallpaper with wood floors and big plate-glass windows and update the traditional pub menu.
Along the way, these chains also became highly sophisticated financial entities. Guy Hands, former private equity specialist at Nomura Securities in London, was the first banker to realize, in 1998, that Britain's steady stream of beer consumption, along with the rental income paid by pub franchises, would translate perfectly into securities. Now there are $6.5 billion in "beer bonds" outstanding, according to Standard & Poor's.
Some pub companies are so well tuned to their sales trends that they rely on complicated financial instruments like weather derivatives to hedge their exposure against cloudy weather, when patrons drink less than on sunny days.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A patron at a London pub owned by Scottish & Newcastle tries one of its brews. The company is taking offers for its 1,500 pubs. (Photo by Bloomberg News)

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 32

LENGTH: 6064 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary, especially in late summer when many galleries close for a few weeks, and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

"A.I.M 23," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, Morrisania, (718) 681-6000 (through Sept. 28). Every year the Bronx Museum puts on a show of work by participants in its Artists in the Marketplace program, which teaches emerging professionals how to manage and advance their careers. Highlights of this year's exhibition include Jeongtae Chae's optically vibrating arrangements of found objects, Joe Fig's miniature re-creations of painters' work tables, Kate Gilmore's video of herself as she tries to bring order to chaos and Hidemi Sato's obliquely poetic grids of photographs depicting brightly colored restaurant and gas station signs against blue sky. Hours: Wednesdays, noon to 9 p.m.; Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+; free on Wednesdays (Ken Johnson).

* "THE AMERICAN EFFECT: GLOBAL PERSPECTIVES ON THE UNITED STATES, 1990-2003," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street (212) 570-3676 (through Oct. 12). Exploring ways that artists throughout the world react to the United States as a superpower, this show of documentary films, videos, installations, photographs, paintings and objects by 47 artists and filmmakers and 3 collaborative groups runs from sunny side up to deep despair. There are reflections on America's military might, its industrial clout, its treatment of minorities, its consumerism, its justice system, its marketing strategies, its religious evangelism, its celebrity worship and its interference with other governments. On the other hand there are more positive expressions of admiration for the freedoms, the opportunities and the material achievements of a country unfettered by ancient traditions. A wacky installation by a French artist, Gilles Barbier, in the form of life-size figures, offers a wry take on the United States through its aging comic book heroes, viewed in the setting of a nursing home and in the last stages of decrepitude. In a very different key is a video projection dealing with the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas in 1963; the work, by a Serbian artist, Zoran Naskovski, is accompanied by a poignantly chanted tribute. The show has its weak spots but overall is provocative and visually compelling. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"ANSEL ADAMS AT 100," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Nov. 3). This exhibition of 113 of Adams's photographs, in celebration of the 100th anniversary of his birth, has been traveling around the world for two years. In these warehouse galleries it has a strangely random and homely feel. The photographs look small and lost. Maybe it's the setting. Maybe it's because the show, organized roughly thematically -- austere peaks, plants, peaks with plants, grand vistas, rocks -- doesn't have a clearly focused concept. Or maybe it's because the curator wanted to tamp down Adams's bombast and replace it with something quieter, smaller and subtler. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays to 7:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Sarah Boxer).

* MAX BECKMANN, Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 29). Like Beckmann, this retrospective of that German genius is dense, frequently revelatory and exhausting: all that heavy-handed symbolism and claustrophobia. Beckmann can seem like a truculent master, glaring balefully at us from his self-portraits, disappointed by our moral turpitude. It is easy to get bogged down in the miasma of his obscure allusions. But he also puts brush to canvas with surprising tenderness. Color is luxurious, not garish. The humor is sly and black. Finally, he is unavoidably compelling. Hours and admission: See above (Michael Kimmelman).

* "BLACK PRESIDENT: THE ART AND LEGACY OF FELA ANIKULAPO-KUTI," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 28). The Nigerian composer, musician and activist Fela Kuti (1938-1997) invented the musical style called Afrobeat, relentlessly assailed political corruption and repression in Africa and beyond through his records and performances, and led a scandalous private life very publicly. This taut, vivacious exhibition is less about the man himself than about how 30 contemporary artists, most of them African or African-American, respond to his blazing, goading lodestar presence. Their reactions range from celebratory to critical, and few are simple, but his vision of a rejuvenated Africa still shines bright. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"LOUISE BOURGEOIS: THE INSOMNIA DRAWINGS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Sept. 21). In an eight-month run of sleep-short nights, the sculptor Louise Bourgeois turned the draggy hours to productive use, setting down thoughts, visions and memories that rose from the floor of her consciousness. What resulted are 250 drawings, considered one work by the artist, that range from simple to complex images: among them water, mazes, clocks, houses, abstract doodles, personal comments and fragments of texts. In short a miscellany of clues to her inner and outer worlds, a scrap bag of images that may prompt her work. But while the dense, insistent visual environment they create is a bit of a phenomenon, the viewer does not really come away with a deeper understanding of the work, whose relationship to Ms. Bourgeois's deeply mined psyche is very evident in her realized art and in statements and interviews she has given over the years. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

"CHALLENGING TRADITION: WOMEN OF THE ACADEMY, 1826 TO 2003," National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Jan. 4). The National Academy's conservatism is reflected in this selection of works by women who enjoyed membership since its beginning in 1825. Few early works rise above decorous academicism, and modest gentility prevails into the 1930's, when Clare Leighton made exquisitely refined wood engravings. There's more excitement in works from the last 50 years. Anne Arnold's ruggedly chiseled portrait in wood of the excellent painter Lois Dodd, Catherine Murphy's acutely observed painting of a sumac forest and Susanna Coffey's intensely compacted painted self-portrait prove traditionalism doesn't have to stultify. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50 for students (Johnson).

"ART CHANTRY: GREATEST HITS, VOL. 1," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-24 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, (718) 784-2084 (through Aug. 31). The argument against graphic design as an art form receives its latest drubbing in this revelatory survey, organized by Robert Nikas and presenting more than 300 posters and album covers by Mr. Chantry, the Seattle-based designer and art director. Dating from the late 1970's to the present, these works capture much of the vitality of that city's underground music and theater scene while defining a maverick sensibility whose inventive low-tech production values and polymorphous recycling of images adds a chapter of its own to the history of appropriation art. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

"CUBA ON THE VERGE: AN ISLAND IN TRANSITION," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). Is it possible for anyone to photograph Cuba without some sort of romance creeping in? The concept behind this show of Cuban, Cuban-American and American photographers was to eschew "cliched images of vintage American cars and other remnants of a prerevolutionary era" and instead to "convey Cuba present," as the show's guest curator, Terry McCoy, writes in the catalog. But some of the photographs suggest that even as Cuba sinks deeper into poverty, ruin and prostitution, the romance of faded beauty and glamorous revolution won't go away. The most refreshing shots are those in which subjects confront the camera and the fantasy. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+ (Boxer).

"SALVADOR DALI: DREAM OF VENUS," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Sept. 7). While images of the 1939 New York World's Fair in Queens remain ingrained in the American collective memory, one attraction, relegated to the "Amusement Zone," was largely forgotten until now: Dali's "Dream of Venus," a tacky Surrealist fun house with live, semi-nude women. This exhibition consists mainly of photographs that document the project from start to finish. Featuring the handsome, charismatic artist; his enigmatic wife, Gala; and lots of voluptuous, unclothed models, this show and its catalog tell a fascinating tale of idealism, opportunism, provocation and censorship. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 55+ (Johnson).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th century Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Johnson).

* "DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF LEWIS CARROLL," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). A photograph is at least as much a looking glass as it is a window. We see in it our own reflections and obsessions. A post-Freudian world has inevitably come to see C. L. Dodgson's photographs through the looking glass of his alter ego, Lewis Carroll. This provocative show tries to put Dodgson's pictures back in their context, to stress that we have lost touch with Victorian conventions, which Dodgson largely obeyed when he photographed little girls. Childhood to Victorians represented, as the show's curator puts it, an "alternate reality, a metaphysical state of preknowledge." Dodgson, he adds, "could pose his charges in adult roles, give them guns, daggers and exotic costumes, even portray them as odalisques and half-dressed waifs, because he and most of his audience believed so emphatically in their total insulation from the implications of such postures." These presentations do not so much underscore the latent sexuality of the child (as we post-Freudians would have it) as they do an obvious lack of it." Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

"ENTERTAINING AMERICA: JEWS, MOVIES AND BROADCASTING," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Sept. 14). Marilyn Monroe's post-conversion mezuza and her music-box menorah are part of the lineup in this bustling roundup devoted to a century of Jewish presence in the entertainment world. A star-studded revue that takes the museum more than a step into showbiz, it covers the 20th century from the early nickelodeons that preceded the Hollywood film industry to recent television manifestations like "Seinfeld," by way of film and video clips, audio tapes, photographs, posters and other artifacts. There is Al Jolson in "The Jazz Singer"; excerpts from Yiddish film and radio; Betty Boop, the sassy personification of a first-generation American Jewish girl from the Lower East Side; and pamphlets railing against Jewish prominence in the movie industry. There are also 10 "star shrines" that celebrate, mostly tongue in cheek, personalities like Sammy Davis Jr., Barbra Streisand and the silent film vamp Theda Bara (really a Jewish girl from Ohio). Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m.; Fridays, to 3 p.m. Admission: $10; $7.50, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "FROM EXPRESSIONISM TOTHE BAUHAUS: HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Sept. 15). Borrowed from the Museum of Modern Art, this economical, powerfully resonant exhibition of German Modernist artworks from the first third of the 20th century includes Expressionist paintings by Ludwig Kirchner, Otto Mueller and Emil Nolde; mordantly satiric New Realist paintings by George Grosz and Otto Dix; and sumptuously elegant utilitarian objects by Marcel Breuer and Marianne Brandt. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"FROM PICASSO TO POLLOCK: CLASSICS OF MODERN ART," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 28). This selective anthology of perennial in-house favorites in a major museum has much to be said for it. The bait is irresistible, the promised classics turn up here and there, and both the young and the not-so-young have a fine time on the ramps. In addition to fine examples by Kandinsky, Picasso, Leger, Chagall, Kokoschka and Malevich, there is an enormous piece in ceramic tiles by Joan Miro. Begun in 1965 and finished in 1967, it is largely in black and white, but every touch of color sings out. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for students and 65+ (John Russell).

* "HENDRICK GOLTZIUS, DUTCH MASTER (1558-1617): DRAWINGS, PRINTS AND PAINTINGS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 7). Goltzius (1558-1617) was one of the hottest of hotshot Dutch artists. He was particularly celebrated for his engravings, many of them mythological tableaus of pumped-up gods and pinup goddesses, rendered in the Mannerist way with flabbergasting elan. But he was also one of the great draftsmen of his age -- his landscape drawings prefigure Rembrandt and Ruisdael -- and became a virtuosic painter whose primary subject was bare human flesh: its texture, its color, its chemistry. To some eyes he remains strictly a period artist; to others he connects to the present in interesting ways. This Met show offers the raw materials for both reactions. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "GREAT WAVES: CHINESE THEMES IN THE ARTS OF KOREA AND JAPAN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 21). Basically a collection reinstallation with a novel mix-and-match approach, this show, spread over both the Chinese painting and Japanese galleries, traces the flow of influence from one culture to the other. Most of the action takes place in the Chinese galleries, where the art is arranged by motifs -- seascapes, landscapes, floral images -- that emerged early in China and circulated to Korea and Japan. The model proposed will provide grist for many scholarly mills in the future; the show itself is tremendous fun to look at. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

JOSE ANTONIO HERNANDEZ-DIEZ, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 21). Born in Venezuela in 1964, Mr. Hernandez-Diez is one of several urbane Latin American artists whose work might be described as a kind of vernacular conceptualism, a physically reductive, idea-rich art made from scraps of everyday consumerist life. His New Museum solo incorporates skateboards, household furniture, a stuffed pet dog, fake fingernails, baseball bats and photographs of designer sneakers, all put to unexpected uses. The results can be read in terms of local associations, but the real focus is on commonly shared experiences: appetite, rootlessness, faith and delusion, violence, the collective unconscious of globalized culture. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Cotter).

* "LANDSCAPE OF MEMORY: THE ART OF MU XIN," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400 (through Sept. 7). The artist and writer Mu Xin, born into a wealthy aristocratic family in China, received a classical scholar's education and early exposure to Western culture. Targeted as a dissident during the Cultural Revolution, he was held in solitary confinement for 18 months, and he secretly wrote a series of first-person meditations now called "Prison Notes," which he carried out of jail sewn in his clothes. Under house arrest several years later, he executed a remarkable series of small landscape paintings in which traditional Chinese themes meet Leonardo da Vinci. The paintings and some of "Prison Notes" are brought together in this lean, penumbral exhibition, organized by the Yale University Art Gallery and the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"LEGENDS OF OUR TIMES: NATIVE RANCHING AND RODEO LIFE ON THE PLAINS AND THE PLATEAU," National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through March 7). This lively account of man, woman and horse among the native people in Western reaches of the United States and Canada proves that a cowboy can be an Indian, and vice versa. The show depicts native peoples not as objects of exploitation by the white man but as ranchers, cowboys, entertainers and rodeo performers. It displays more than 700 objects -- saddles, bead and quill works, paintings, photographs, blankets, clothing, horse gear, hunting implements, roundup equipment, headdresses and other ceremonial garb -- from the 18th century to now. At least half of this huge show provides an engaging and comprehensive account of rodeo, but nonrodeo fans will probably have more fun with the bedazzlement of objects depicting the more traditional side of American Indian life. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free (Glueck).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through October). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 65+ (Smith).

"PULP ART: VAMPS, VILLAINS AND VICTORS FROM THE ROBERT LESSER COLLECTION," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 31). This murky exhibition showcases the small, gaudy, largely unappreciated paintings commissioned for the covers of the pulp magazines that ruled the newsstands between the wars. While ultimately a bit repetitious, their overheated depictions of sharp-jawed heroes, compromised heroines and various human and nonhuman villains highlight talents like George Rozen and Paul R. Frank. They also give vent to the dark, violent, libidinous underbelly of the American psyche, to the same degree that Norman Rockwell's paintings bless its wholesome, repressed, preternaturally sunny side. The show is essential viewing for anyone interested in popular culture past or present. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Smith).

"SITE AND INSIGHT: AN ASSEMBLAGE OF ARTISTS," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Aug. 31). Agnes Gund, former president of the Museum of Modern Art, a major collector and longtime supporter of the arts, is the curator of a generally bland show of works by 15 artists she has followed over the years. Highlights include Ellen Phelan's elegant, soft-focus landscape paintings; gnarly junk assemblages by Bruce Conner and Arthur Simms; Peter Campus's hypnotic, semi-abstracted video landscapes; and best of all Jim Hodges's enormous curtain made of hundreds of fake flowers stitched together. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission, $5; $2 for students and 62+ (Johnson).

"USDESIGN 1975-2000," Museum of Arts & Design, 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535 (through Nov. 2). This survey of objects designed during the 20th century's last quarter is disappointing, partly because few of the products on view are very interesting to look at and partly because it sheds so little light on a field that has expanded in a mind-boggling variety of directions in recent years. Focused mainly on consumer goods like chairs, clocks, lamps, teapots, telephones, sneakers, ski boots, roller blades, sunglasses and computers, it has the feel of an outmoded department store. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"WILLEM VAN TETRODE: BRONZE SCULPTURES OF THE RENAISSANCE," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Sept. 7). This exhibition introduces a neglected Dutch artist who flourished amid the cultural ferment of 16th-century Italy, when the rediscoveries of monumental Classical marbles helped fuel a passion for mythological themes, the rise of private collecting and a new sense of physical and emotional drama in sculpture. Prodigiously talented, van Tetrode navigated his own path between Classicism and Mannerism with beautifully detailed bronzes, most notably a splendidly muscled and bearded Hercules dispatching various labors with violent panache. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Smith).

"VIETNAM: JOURNEYS OF BODY, MIND AND SPIRIT," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through Jan. 4). For many Americans who came of age before or during the 1960's, Vietnam was the name of a place you didn't want to go. Even today the prevailing impression of this part of Southeast Asia seems to be a composite of remembered news clips and scenes from "Apocalypse Now." More than a quarter-century after the war, the image is due for revision, and that is the basic idea behind this show, a lavishly illustratedanthropological field trip through Vietnam today. Using objects, videos and photographs it examines popular traditions associated with marriage, death and religion, often to vivid effect, in a lively, serpentine installation. And even with many important political and social questions left unasked and unanswered, there is a wealth of information here. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $9, students and 60+ (Cotter).

"ANDY WARHOL: SCREEN TESTS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 1). From 1964 to 1966 Warhol shot 500 short, silent, black-and-white films of artists, musicians, actors, writers, filmmakers, models, curators, celebrities and hangers-on at the Factory. The Modern has restored 277 of these screen tests, representing about 34 hours of watching time, and now 28 of the films are being shown continuously on six screens. The subjects include Baby Jane Holzer, Salvador Dali, James Rosenquist, Dennis Hopper, Cass Elliott and Susan Sontag, but they are of variable interest. By shooting the films at one speed and playing them more slowly, Warhol exposed the mechanics of discomposure and charisma. Some people are fascinating as they lose charisma; others are not. It has nothing to do with handsomeness, histrionics, coolness, slimness, trying or giving up. The typology of charisma is as elusive as the typology of criminality. Hours and admission: See above (Boxer).

Galleries: Uptown

TED FAIERS, "Paintings From the 1950's," Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through Aug. 29). Indian Space painting was a mid-20th-century American movement that mixed Cubist abstraction with American Indian-style patterns and pictographs. Faiers's exercises in that now dimly remembered style have at best an appealing jazziness and chromatic radiance. There is something ultimately silly, though, about the idea of the sophisticated urbanite getting in touch with his inner shaman (Johnson).

TONY FOSTER, "Watermarks," James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Aug. 29). Mr. Foster is yet another Englishman whose art revolves around travel. Finding his way from South American tropical forests to glaciers in Greenland, he neatly documents what he sees in watercolor; he then adds found objects like bones, shells, vials of water, rocks and feathers. The art in the gallery is not as adventurous as the artist himself seems to be (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* HELMUT FEDERLE, "Works on Paper," Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Sept. 13). From the mid-1970's to the late 90's, the Swiss-born painter Helmut Federle extended his imagery from geometricized but lush mountain peaks to the freest of signs and markings. The 200 drawings on view here trace his progress. Although the work remains in a highly reductive geometricized mode, it is sometimes quirkily dreamy and sensuous, with more than a touch of whimsy. In these 200 drawings, which gain strength by from being grouped together, Mr. Federle's many and varied passes at the paper range from the precise scientific textbook rendering "Constellation" (1983) to more relaxed and painterly grids like "Untitled" (1992), in which eroded bright blue bands are dragged across a white ground. He is a great performer; even his most fragmentary wisps hold the eye (Glueck).

Galleries: Chelsea

"BOYS OF SUMMER," ClampArt, 531 West 25th Street, (646) 230-0020 (tomorrow through Sept. 6). If you like to look at men, and you're passing by, stop in. Standing out among the crowd of pictures by more than two dozen photographers are "Bruce in His Car," a 1981 portrait of a skinny bohemian in his big red convertible by Nan Goldin; a beefy, shirtless young football player celebrating with his team, by Brian Finke; men in leather, by Barbara Nitke; and, by Malerie Marder, a large color image of a mixed-sex group of naked people relaxing in a California bathhouse (Johnson).

* "HALF AIR," Marianne Boesky, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9889 (through Aug. 29). Everything in this fascinating reliquary of a show looks as if it was exhumed from some moldy basement. It includes enigmatic, semi-abstract symbolist paintings by Forrest Bess; mesmerizing, diagrammatic linear compositions by Genn Branca; videos of the performance artist Charlemagne Palestine whipping himself into Dionysian frenzies; snapshots documenting the demimonde of the performance artist Jack Smith; and scenes from a Wooster Group film featuring the seaside antics of cross-dressed nuns (Johnson).

* "IN FULL VIEW," Andrea Rosen, 525 West 24th Street, (212) 627-6000 (through Sept. 13). A show that invites visitors on a pluralistic treasure hunt for 18 artworks that tease one's limits of visual perception. Look for Christopher Chiappa's Ford Taurus gas-tank door built into the wall; Maurizio Cattelan's roosting stuffed pigeons; Vincent Shine's tiny, gold Brancusian wasp; Jim Hodges's jewelry-chain spiderweb and Charles Ray's classic "Rotating Disc" (Johnson).

"SPLIT," Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, (646) 336-7183 (through Sept. 6). The best thing in this six-person show is Xavier Veilhan's bigger-than-life skeleton woven in wicker; it slouches casually in a corner of the gallery, a marvel of exotic faux-folk art. Note, too, a dense mix of cartoon characters and abstract patterning painted collaboratively in gouache by Christian Schumann and Gary Panter (Johnson).

"THIS IS LAGOS: YABIS NIGHT, MUSIC AND FELA," Skoto, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-8058 (through Sept. 13). If you crave a second fix of the charismatic Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti after seeing "Black President" at the New Museum, Skoto is the place go. Much of this gallery's fine summer show is devoted to vivid pictures of Fela by the Nigerian photographer Femi Bankole Osunla, who was part of Fela's inner circle from the early 1970's to the musician's death from AIDS in 1997. This work is complemented by a handsome series of color images of Africa by the American photographer Howard T. Cash, two heads sculptured by Osaretin Ighile and an alterlike installation by the young American artist Sol Sax (Cotter).

"VACATION," Spike, 547 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4100 (through Sept. 20). Innocence and experience collide in the works of Norm Magnusson, who outlines juvenile, coloring-book-style images over gridded fields of pages from pointedly selected books. Jesus offering guidance to a little boy is drawn over pages from Bulfinch's "Mythology," for example, and paper-doll clothes over "Lolita." Also on view: Buck Henri's engaging photographs of exotic dancers, old cars, mannequins, small-town parades and other subjects; Alan Schmer's illustrative paintings of farm animals; and Melissa Stern's pedestal-size figurative sculptures that blend Surrealism and primitivism (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "RAINING ELEPHANTS," Little Cakes Little Gallery, 240 East Fourth Street, Apt. 1D, East Village, (212) 979-9736 (through Aug. 31). This new apartment gallery opens up with a delightful show of work by the Pennsylvania artist Ed Wilcox and the Virginia collective Dearraindrop. Mr. Wilcox, who is in a band, works with several mediums, including painting, collage, sculpture and copying machines, with which he conjurs finely wrought, hallucinatory cartoon images. Dearraindrop specializes in what might be called collages of collages, incrementally covering the walls of the gallery with patches of fabric, cut paper, photographs, record album covers and paint. There is a library's worth of free-associational material here. Best of all, though, is their rapid-fire, eye-tickling video, a time-capsule of pop culture put through a shredder. The gallery is open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. (Cotter).

Last Chance

ANSEL ADAMS, "100 + 1," Robert Mann, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-2947 (through today). Great modern artist or purveyor of high-toned kitsch? Coinciding with the retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art in Queens, this substantial show affords a fine occasion to weigh the evidence. Looking at Adams's skillfully manipulated Wild West landscapes, one feels less awakened to the wondrous complexities of photography and nature than bludgeoned by a proto-Spielbergian romanticism (Johnson).

"FRANKENSTEIN (OR IT'S ALL FUN AND GAMES UNTIL SOMEONE LOSES AN EYE)," Tanya Bonakdar, 521 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 414-4144, (through today). Organized by Ethan Sklar, the gallery's director, this exhibition examines the ways artists subvert the physical and decision-making processes of art making by using machines, accident, science, random selection and all-inclusiveness and has a title perfectly suited to its sometimes scary weirdness (Smith).

"FROM GASLIGHTS TO TELEVISION," Susan Teller, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 941-7335 (through Thursday). Typewriters, stoves, refrigerators, clocks, pumps, sewing machines, telephones, fans, ice cream makers, irons and other labor-saving devices turn up in this surprising show about appliances in 20th-century American domestic life. From John Sloan's sexy etching of a woman turning off the light before joining her lover in bed to Louise Leech's painting of her teenage daughters watching the first Moon landing on television, the show conjures an engagingly humane vision of living with modern technology (Johnson).

"H2O," Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through today). For obvious reasons a lot of summer group shows take water as a theme, this one more directly and more effectively than most. Works by more than 30 artists include Sally Mann's mysterious photograph of three naked, nubile girls urinating; a piece of magic illusionism by Amy Jenkins that has a bathing woman video-projected into a miniature bathtub; Laura Aguilar's portrait of her own mountainously corpulent self lying naked next to a small rock pool; and a gigantically enlarged sweat gland reproduced in rubber by Jeanne Silverthorne (Johnson).

"PROTEST," Pace-McGill, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7999 (through Tuesday). This timely group show is a photographic survey of late-20th-century political history, mostly American, seen from the perspective of people who refused to accept what history and politics were handing them. Breathtaking aerial views by Bob Adelman and Bruce Davidson of the 1963 Civil Rights march in Washington hang near a 1959 shot by Constantine Manos of a Ku Klux Klan cross-burning in South Carolina. Both events were bold political theater but generated from opposite ends of the ethical spectrum. Sometimes single images pack ambivalent messages. In Burt Glinn's heroizing -- or is it mock-heroizing? -- shot of Fidel Castro surrounded by rifle-toting revolutionaries we see a liberation movement in the process of turning into a repressive new status quo. The flames of resistance, the lesson seems to be, can blow in unpredictable directions (Cotter).

* "RAFAEL TUFINO: PAINTER OF THE PEOPLE," El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272 (through Sunday). Mr. Tufino was born in Brooklyn in 1930 but has spent most of his life in Puerto Rico. There are many individual images to savor in this retrospective of his paintings and prints, but it is Mr. Tufino himself who is radiant. His cosmopolitan presence in Puerto Rico and New York has encouraged generations of artists prone to view themselves as confined to a backwater, helping them to feel part of a larger world and to feel that the world they lived in is larger than they knew. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $6; $4 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "THE WORLD OF BUDDHISM: SELECTIONS FROM THE MR. AND MRS. JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER III COLLECTION," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Sunday). Anyone familiar with the Rockefeller collection is already feeling blissed out by its return to public view. Everyone else will have the delight of a first-time encounter with embodiment of the Buddha in many forms, from an earthly stone figure carved in fifth-century India, to the celestial eighth-century bronze Buddha of the Future, probably made in northern Thailand, and now one of the great art sights of New York. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Weekender Stonington, Conn.

BYLINE:  By GEORGINA GUSTIN 

 BODY:
A RATHER affluent, rather literary little village." That characterization of the borough of Stonington, Conn., by Uday Mehta, a professor of political science at Amherst College, may be something of an understatement. For years Stonington, on a quiet peninsula that juts into Long Island Sound, has lured intellectual, wealthy urbanites drawn by its almost islandlike feeling.
 "It's very self-contained," said Inger McCabe Elliott, a photojournalist and designer who lives on Water Street with her husband, Osborn Elliott, a former editor of Newsweek. 
 The shelves of the village bookstore are stocked with titles by resident authors, past and present, including James Merrill, J. D. McClatchy, Peter Benchley and Eleanor Perenyi. And the borough is about to build a firehouse designed by Philip Johnson's architectural firm. 
Yet you can buy native scallops from a local fisherman's freezer, day or night, by putting cash into a slot. The influx of affluent residents and second-home owners has displaced most of the Portuguese fishing families who built a robust village economy in the 19th century, but not all. The state's last remaining commercial fleet still calls the borough home.
"The fleet is really the heart and soul of the village," said Andrew M. Maynard, the borough's warden, whose job is roughly what a mayor's would be. "It adds immeasurably."
Now, on Main Street, one of the two primary thoroughfares in the borough, you will still find the Portuguese Holy Ghost Society, but you will also find renovated captain's houses. The borough, which is the historic center of the sprawling town of Stonington, is simple and grand at the same time, with plain fishermen's cottages wedged next to each other and pillared homes facing Fishers Island Sound.
"I think of it as having a kind of understated charm," said Mr. Mehta, who recently bought a second home there.
The borough is on Fishers Island Sound, an area of Long Island Sound between the Connecticut shoreline and Fishers Island. Bell buoys and foghorns provide the soundtrack to the banter on Water Street as people go to Tom's News for the papers in the morning or out for cocktails in the evenings. The borough's size, less than one square mile, with just 1,200 residents, makes it a walking-friendly place, and the streets are the social backbone of the community.
It is one of several villages within the town of Stonington, but is its own political entity, run by a Board of Warden and Burgesses, which oversees everything from sanitation to sidewalks. Several weekend residents have been board members.
"Stonington is not a resort town," Ms. Elliott said. "It's a village."

The Scene
The proximity of the houses in the borough creates an intimate social dynamic. "It's one of the charms and one of the drawbacks," said Ned Davies, a dealer at a Chelsea art gallery who divides his weeks between his 1760 Colonial house in Stonington and his Greenwich Village apartment. "You have to like that kind of social interaction."
In the mid-1990's, Mr. Davies started a Web site, The Stonington Intelligencer (www.stoningtonct.com), where he posts small village news items and book reviews by local academics and writers.
"We found out there was a dearth of parochial information," he said. Now, he laughed, "you can plug in from London and find out who hit the tree -- the important things, the things we talk about at dinner."
The Intelligencer's Web cam shows a view of Diving Street. "It's been a huge hit," Mr. Davies said. "People like to see what the weather's like."
The Intelligencer has also become a forum for discussion of borough affairs, from zoning disputes to benefit auctions for the Stonington Free Library.
"Going to some of the town meetings is pretty fun," said Michael Adair, a high school teacher from Bedford, N.Y., who bought a home on Water Street last year. "It's entertainment."
Alice Fitzpatrick, who moved to the borough from California six years ago, has found not only what she calls "an antidote to the anonymity of L.A.," but an unusual social group.
She is a member of the Waccos, for Women Alone in a Cooperative Community, a collective of single women in the borough who have banded together and formed a support system.
"Instead of a taxi, you call a Wacco," said Beth Walker, who formed the group shortly after moving to the borough in the early 90's when she stepped back from daily management of her business, the Walker Publishing Company. "It's an extraordinarily caring community."
That is a side of Stonington that many people do not see, some residents say. "Most people think it's a snooty, yachty place," Ms. Fitzpatrick said, "but that's not been my experience."

Pros
Stonington is a boater's paradise. The borough alone has two boat yards, 400 town moorings and two yacht clubs, the new Stonington Harbor Yacht Club and the Wadawanuck Yacht Club. Though the wait to join the Wadawanuck can be years, Stonington Harbor can take members right away, and because the town recently adopted a new harbor management plan, the wait for town moorings, which used to be as long as 10 years, is now just a season or two.
The Stonington Community Center, known as the Como to locals, has summer programs and sponsors film showings at duBois Beach, the town of Stonington's only public beach.
The borough has four restaurants and one of the largest farmers' markets in Connecticut, held at the town docks. The whole town celebrates at the Fourth of July potluck dinner on the lawn by the Old Lighthouse Museum, which sits at the end of the peninsula. (This year's dinner went forward despite a huge late-night fire on July 3 that destroyed an old factory building on Water Street, leaving a charred husk along the waterfront and damaging nearby homes.) 
The borough is tucked away on its peninsula and has less tourist traffic than many other picturesque seaside towns, but some residents like the winters, when the visitors go away. "I hear only the seagulls, the bell buoys and the distant train whistle," said the poet J. D. McClatchy, who, with his partner, the graphic designer and author Chip Kidd, divides his time between the borough and an apartment in Little Italy. "It's gray, it's lonely, but those are the perfect conditions for a writer."

Cons
Few houses in the borough have any substantial amount of land.
Because the borough is a historic district, zoning laws are very strict, so anyone wanting to experiment architecturally will not get a warm reception.
Parking is limited, and in the summer residents often find their favorite roadside spots taken by tourists.
Residents lament the disappearance of amenities within walking distance. Two decades ago, the borough had a hardware store, a drug store and three grocery stores. Now, antiques shops predominate.
Stonington is expensive. Property values and taxes have increased sharply in the last decade, forcing out people of limited means.

The Real Estate Market
Prices for homes for sale in the borough range from $299,000 for a modest three-bedroom, two-bathroom house built in 1900 on the side of the train tracks away from the peninsula, to $5.9 million for a totally refurbished estate with five bedrooms and eight bathrooms in the heart of the borough. There are 13 active listings on the market in the borough this week.
Outside the borough, prices for houses in the town of Stonington start at $99,000. "The borough is one of four peninsulas that go into the ocean," said Stuart Cole of Cole Real Estate (860-535-1953), "and each of these peninsulas have a mini-market." On Wamphassuc Point, opposite the borough on Stonington Harbor, prices are comparable to those in the borough. On Latimer and Lord's Points, costs are lower. But generally, little shoreline property is for sale.
Cole Real Estate has listed the 1870 Zebulan Hancox house, near the tip of the peninsula in the borough, with three bedrooms and one and a half baths, for $475,000.
The average house in the borough ranges in price from $600,000 to $800,000, according to Nancy Tapley, a real estate agent with Pequot Properties in nearby Mystic (860-536-4906). "You can buy in the threes, but you'll need to do $100,000 of work," she said. "If you want a water view, it's $700,000 and up."
This week Pequot Properties was offering a 1,700-square-foot Cape built in 1914 for $350,000, and a 2,300-square-foot, six-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath Victorian for $450,000.
Christine Wright, a real estate agent with Coldwell Banker, which has offices in the borough (860-535-1882), said the market was "holding its own."
"The prices aren't coming down," she said, "but the days on the market, or D.O.M., as we call it, is increasing."
This week Coldwell Banker was offering a two-bedroom, two-bathroom expanded Cape built in 1765 for $698,000 and a newly built colonial-style house with three bedrooms, two bathrooms and water views for $750,000.

LAY OF THE LAND
A Borough for Boaters and Book Lovers

POPULATION -- About 1,200 (of 17,984 in the larger town of Stonington).
SIZE -- Less than a square mile.
MEDIAN HOUSE PRICE -- $698,000 in the borough; $498,000 for the town.
RECENT SALES -- An 1840 house in the heart of the borough of Stonington, with five bedrooms, three bathrooms and five working fireplaces, sold for $840,000; an 1880 house with four bedrooms and two bathrooms, with a water view, sold for $545,000; an 1871 colonial-style house with five bedrooms and four bathrooms on the waterfront, with a separate one-bedroom apartment, sold for $995,000.
DISTANCE FROM NEW YORK -- 140 miles.
TRAVEL TIME -- In light traffic, three hours.
GETTING THERE -- Take Interstate 95 northbound to Exit 91, marked toward North Main Street/Stonington Borough. Turn right onto Pequot Trail/Route 234 and drive about a third of a mile to North Main Street. Follow North Main Street for 2.3 miles to Trumbull Avenue and go left. Take Trumbull to Alpha Avenue and go right. Alpha Avenue leads straight into the borough.
WHILE YOU'RE LOOKING -- The 18-room Inn at Stonington (860-535-2000), which opened in 2001, has rooms for $175 to $295 during midweek, and for $195 to $395 on weekends.

HEADLINE: New Video Releases 

 BODY:
Bowling for Columbine
 In the good-natured confrontational style of his 1989 documentary "Roger and Me," Michael Moore, left, tracks gun violence far and wide, beginning with the massacre at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo. Larger questions include why Americans shoot one another much more frequently than people in other developed countries do and why they are so inclined when other societies are as inundated with violent entertainment and as affected by unemployment and other strains. But though Mr. Moore seems to be digging for specific historical causes, he indulges in glib generalizations and oversimplifications. When he goes against his prejudices, his appraisal is riveting and scary, but "the slippery logic, tendentious grandstanding and outright demagoguery on display in 'Bowling for Columbine' should give pause to its most ardent partisans," A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. 

2002. MGM. VHS, $49.99; DVD, $26.90. 119 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

The Good Thief
Neil Jordan's remake of Jean-Pierre Melville's atmospheric, poetic film noir "Bob le Flambeur" heightens the combustion by a few cylinders. As played by Nick Nolte, Bob is an old trickster with his cards close to his vest. A gambler and heroin addict, he kicks the habit long enough to become involved in a casino heist. A towering figure of the Nice demimonde, Bob seems able to get away with just about anything and finds an advantage even when he doesn't. That kind of cool and sense of irony puts Bob beyond torment. It also attracts a beautiful 18-year-old Russian emigree (Nutsa Kukhianidze). "Mr. Jordan has the right actor for the task. Mr. Nolte uses 'The Good Thief' as a haven for a majestic ruin he has worked at for years" (Elvis Mitchell).

2003. Fox. VHS, $110.99; DVD, $27.90. 109 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

All the Real Girls
A self-assured 18-year-old named Noel (Zooey Deschanel) returns from a girls' boarding school and tells her would-be boyfriend, Paul (Paul Schneider), that she's passing up college because she doesn't see much point in spending four years writing bad-girl poetry. Paul tells her she'll find plenty of bad poetry around her North Carolina hometown, but the pair's sweet, inconclusive romance has lyricism in the second filmby David Gordon Green ("George Washington"). With unabashed sincerity and tenderness, Mr. Green "captures both the world-stopping intensity and the delicate absurdity of youthful longing, and Paul and Noel themselves are at once gawkily real and luminously peculiar" (Scott).

2003. Columbia TriStar. VHS, $54.99; DVD, $24.95. 108 minutes. Closed captioned. R.

Straight to Video

Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release, appeared on television or been on videocassette or DVD in earlier editions.

I'M GOING HOME. In Manoel de Oliveira's film, the 75-year-old Michel Piccoli is Gilbert Valence, a distinguished French actor performing scenes as a dying monarch in Ionesco's "Exit the King," as Prospero in "The Tempest" and as Buck Mulligan in a screen adaptation of Joyce's "Ulysses." Mr. Piccoli is the alter ego of the Portuguese-born Mr. de Oliveira, who was 92 when this film was made. Old age doesn't automatically confer wisdom and artistic profundity, but when it does, as in the case of Mr. de Oliveira, "what can emerge is a remarkable mixture of appreciation and sadness, colored with an implacable, clear-eyed awareness of looming extinction," Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. The DVD has a commentary by Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center. 2001. Milestone. VHS, $29.95; DVD, $29.99. 90 minutes. French with English subtitles. Information: (800) 603-1104.

MARYAM. In 1979, with American hostages being held in Iran, a 16-year-old Iranian-American girl (Mariam Parris) tries to fit into her suburban New Jersey world. Ramin Serry's film falters when he reaches for drama, but he works well with a gifted cast that has a feel for emotional details. "Ms. Parris, a quicksilver young talent who projects common sense, is a real find," Elvis Mitchell wrote in The Times. 2000. Wellspring. VHS, $49.98. DVD, $24.90. 90 minutes. No rating.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Telecom Role In Decline, JDS Uniphase Gets New Boss

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Aug. 21 

 BODY:
JDS Uniphase, a maker of telecommunications components whose stock was among the highest of the highfliers in the late 1990's, announced a major shake-up in its executive ranks today. 
 Jozef Straus, 57, one of the company's founders, is retiring as chief executive and co-chairman, and will be replaced by Kevin Kennedy, formerly chief operating officer of Openwave Systems Inc. of Redwood City, Calif., which makes mobile phone and messaging software. He had earlier worked in the optical networking division of Cisco Systems. 
 JDS Uniphase also said that Syrus Madavi, its chief operating officer, had resigned. 
Mr. Kennedy, 47, said today that his priority was to continue a cost-reduction plan for JDS Uniphase, which makes components to increase the speed and capacity of fiber optic networks. While he has been on the company's board for the last two years, "I don't feel encumbered by history," he said. 
Under Mr. Straus, JDS Uniphase went on an acquisition binge. During the late 1990's, its fiber optic equipment was in high demand from companies like Lucent Technologies and Nortel Networks. But the telecommunications-spending bubble burst, and JDS has spent the last two years grappling with the slump in demand. 
In July 2001, JDS wrote down by $44.8 billion the value of companies it had acquired in the two previous years. For its fiscal year that ended June 30, the company reported a loss of $934 million. 
JDS has reduced its work force from a peak of almost 20,000 in 2001 to 5,500 now, and said today that in the future it would have a single head office in San Jose, Calif. 
For the last four years, it has maintained a second headquarters in Nepean, Ontario, near Ottawa, stemming from its $7 billion acquisition of JDS Fitel, a Canadian maker of fiber optic equipment.
Mr. Straus, known for his beret and beard, has worked for JDS for 20 years. He said that the chief operating officer, Mr. Madavi, 54, had initially been considered the leading candidate to succeed him. Mr. Madavi and the board had discussed their "mutual perspectives," Mr. Straus said, and after "much deliberation and careful consideration of these perspectives," the board decided to give the job to Mr. Kennedy. 
Dennis Gallagher, an analyst with the SoundView Technology Group of Old Greenwich, Conn., expressed surprise that Mr. Madavi had not been offered the top job. Despite continuing losses, JDS had made considerable progress, he said, by trimming a large chunk of midlevel management, expanding its Asian business and using its technology to develop products outside its traditional business in the telecommunications and cable TV sectors.
Shares of JDS rose 31 cents today, or nearly 10 percent, to $3.50 in Nasdaq trading. In March 2000, the stock traded above $146.
JDS has faced intensifying competition in the components sector from suppliers like Intel and Hitachi and Furukawa Electric of Japan. Almost half of JDS's revenue now comes from nontelecommunications customers. Asia accounted for 13 percent of sales in the fourth quarter.
Earlier this year, JDS bought LA Label, a maker of pressure-sensitive labels based in Commerce, Calif. JDS said that its optical technology could be integrated into labels and packaging to protect branded products against counterfeiting. 
The company has also increasingly moved into assembling its components into modules. "That's what the customers want," Mr. Gallagher said.
When JDS released its latest financial results last month, it said that it expected sales to slip further, to $145 million to $155 million, in the current quarter, from $161 million in the three months to June and $222 million a year earlier. It said that it expected to break even on an operating basis in the quarter ending June 30, 2004, assuming sales of $170 million to $200 million.
Arnab Chanda, an analyst with Lehman Brothers in San Francisco, said, "The company has done fine considering their business has not improved."
"But there are still a lot of things to fix," he said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Bush Tries to Put Focus on Domestic Policy, but Events Conspire Against Him

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Ore., Aug. 21 

 BODY:
With two big forest fires darkening the skies near here, President Bush could hardly have had a more compelling setting today to promote his approach to reduce the risk of devastating blazes. He even took a bumpy helicopter ride for a close-up look, providing another of the made-for-television images that the White House uses skillfully.
 But with the ruins from terrorist attacks smoldering halfway across the globe, Mr. Bush's efforts to burnish his environmental credentials, court moderate voters and focus the nation on domestic matters struggled for traction. The attention of the news media and much of the world remained riveted by the Mideast violence and the growing terrorist threat in Iraq. Today served mostly as a reminder of how much Mr. Bush's standing is hostage to his foreign policy and events abroad. 
 Since Mr. Bush landed on the carrier Abraham Lincoln on May 1 under a banner proclaiming "Mission Accomplished," the White House has tried to refocus its message to domestic concerns, starting with the economy but extending to other issues vital to the strategy of claiming the political center.
Starting a day after flying to the Lincoln, he stepped up promotion of his domestic agenda on points like tax cuts, health care, energy and limits on lawsuit awards. Today in Oregon, a state he lost by fewer than 7,000 votes, Mr. Bush was distracted from his plan to expand logging as a way to thin forests and reduce fire risk. On Friday in neighboring Washington, he is to make a case for how his policies on hydroelectric dams and river management have led to a salmon resurgence.
If only the world will listen. With television images and newspaper headlines focused on the violence overseas and what it says about leadership on antiterrorism, "there is always the potential for taking away the White House's strategy and message of focusing on the economy, health care, the environment and swing voters," said James A. Thurber, director of the Center for Congressional and Presidential Studies at American University in Washington. 
To some degree, the focus on an unstable threat-filled world works to Mr. Bush's advantage. His position as commander in chief of an open-ended war on terrorism is the foundation of his standing and a difficult credential for his would-be Democratic challengers to overcome.
Polls show that voters are far more concerned about the economy than terrorism and that they give Mr. Bush far lower marks on the economy and domestic issues generally than on foreign policy. Moreover, Mr. Bush's foreign policy ratings are also falling as Washington encounters problems in Iraq.
In a New York Times/CBS News poll last month, 52 percent of respondents disapproved of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, with 40 percent approving. A poll this month by the Pew Research Center found that the number of people saying the military effort in Iraq was going very well had fallen, to 19 percent from 61 percent in April. The same poll found that 57 percent of respondents said Mr. Bush should primarily focus on the economy versus 27 percent who said he should focus on terrorism. At the beginning of the year, 43 percent said he should focus on terrorism and 38 percent said he should focus on the economy.
Mr. Bush's overall approval ratings, while still strong, have also fallen, from more than 70 percent in many polls in the war to below 60 percent in many polls.
"The question is how long can his ratings hold up while the Iraq situation seems to go from bad to worse, and can he get traction on his domestic agenda when people are distracted constantly by Iraq and the Middle East," said Andrew Kohut, executive director of the Pew Research Center.
The focus on events abroad "does emphasize his strong point, but his strong point is getting weaker," Mr. Kohut said.
Mr. Bush did his part to stay on message today. In two speeches, he did not mention the announcement by Palestinian terrorists that they were declaring an end to their cease-fire with Israel. Nor did he mention the bombing on Tuesday in Baghdad, and he took no questions from reporters.
Even when he managed to command attention on the domestic front, Mr. Bush faced challenges. As his motorcade whisked him to a $1 million fund-raiser in Portland, he passed unusually large numbers of protesters, despite approaching by what seemed to be a back route. Environmental groups issued statements condemning his forest policy as a sop to the timber industry.
In both appearances, Mr. Bush acknowledged the uncomfortable reality for him that Oregon's unemployment rate, at 7.8 percent, was far above the national rate of 6.2 percent.
He received a warm reception here from a crowd of several hundred people who sat in a brisk breeze that fanned the fires on the horizon and applauded when he said the nation should leave behind what he called the "propaganda of what it means to protect forests."
